characters: EXT. EDO RODRIGUES' HOUSE IN CHRISTIAN RESIDENCE YARD DAY
INT. EDO RODRIGUES' HOUSE IN CHRISTIAN RESIDENCE DUSK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The faces of FIVE MEN appear out of a thick cloud of mist rising off a seething lake of boiling water. They look li pale phantoms. Terrified. We HEAR the voice of FATHER CHRISTOVAO FERREIRA. Strong. Resolute.

dialogues.speaker: FERREIRA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (reading) "Good Friday, 1633. Pax Christi. Praised be God. Although for us there is little peace in this land now."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we see FERREIRA. He is a Jesuit priest. A missionary. the look on his face does not match the reflective tone o voice we are hearing. He is troubled at something he sees turns away... .--but two GUARDS, holding him, force him to look back. V of steam make them seem like creatures in a dream.

dialogues.speaker: FERREIRA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (reading) "I never knew Japan when it was a country of light. But I have never known it to be as dark as it is now.” On those last words, Ferreira is pulled, through the stea into close-up. He struggles not to show the pain of what sees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The five men are surrounded by SAMURAI and various OFFICI Guards are pushing them forward. The five men are THREE AUGUSTINIAN FRIARS, a FRANCISCAN FRIAR and a JAPANESE JES PRIEST.

dialogues.speaker: FERREIRA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “All our progress has ended in new persecution, new repression, new suffering. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FERREIRA(V.O.) (cont'd) The governor of Nagasaki first hoped to destroy our Christian faith with ridicule, and by example.” Steam from the hot spring ebbs briefly to reveal the men Catholic priests. Their hands are tied. The water in fron them is like a cauldron.

dialogues.speaker: FERREIRA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “But when the faithful resisted, and refused to renounce God, he became more cruel." In a grove of trees on a small rise in the near distance, Guards hold tight to the priest Ferreira, making sure he doesn’t miss a thing. They yank Ferreira like a dog on a Closer to the spring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The five priests tremble at the edge of the scorching spr

dialogues.speaker: FERREIRA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "He took four friars and one of our own Society to Unzen. There are hot springs there. The Japanese call them '‘hells,' partly I think in mockery, and partly, I must tell you, in truth." The cold air makes the STEAM rise thickly from the lake.

dialogues.speaker: FERREIRA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "The officials told the faithful to abandon God and the gospel of His love. But they not only refused to apostatize. They asked to be tortured, so they could demonstrate the strength of their faith and the presence of God within them." The water throws scalding spray into the air, burning the of one of the priests. Nearby, still guarded by the samurai, Ferreira bites his control himself. His lip bleeds. He watches as... ...the captured priest turns, unbroken, to his captors, refusing to capitulate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Praise to you, Lord Jesus Christ! (alt: Soul of Christ, sanctify me!) Showing no anger, an Official makes an abrupt gesture. Gu tear off the priests’ garments then dip long-handled ladl into the boiling water of the spring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seen now from a distance, as if on a stage: guards approa five Christian prisoners, who are tied nearly naked to wo stakes. The guards DRIP the scalding water onto their bod

dialogues.speaker: FERREIRA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "They used ladles filled with holes so the drops would come out slowly, and the pain would be prolonged. Each small splash of the water was like a burning coal." The crowd surges forward.

dialogues.speaker: FERREIRA
dialogues.text: "Some remained on the mountain for 33 days."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A month later. Still from a distance: The five Christians being untied from the stakes. Their bodies are wracked fr effects of exposure.

dialogues.speaker: FERREIRA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “The story of their courage has become almost legend. They give hope to those of us who remain here, against the shogun’s order, to teach the faith. We only grow stronger, in His love.” Near the hot spring, Ferreira collapses to the ground. Hi guard lets him fall. He hides his face in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TITLE UP: COLLEGE OF MADRE DE DEUS / MACAO / Spring, 1640 hand places a letter on a desk and Father Valignano remov spectacles, reciting the last words of the letter. He kno them well.

dialogues.speaker: VALIGNANO
dialogues.text: Ferreira is lost to us. (looks up) This was his last letter. Valignano is a compelling man, the senior Jesuit superior this mission on the very edge of the known world. He look across at TWO YOUNG PRIESTS, neither older than thirty, w seated before him. One priest, FRANCISCO GARUPE, who has the lean, restless appearance of a hunting animal, looks thoughtful. He is measuring his response... ...-when the second priest speaks. He has an aspect of sp assurance about him, of untested righteousness, but there hungry, haunted look in his eyes, too. He's like a man wh seen his own ghost. His name is SEBASTIAO RODRIGUES.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: That was so long ago. It says nothing of him now.

dialogues.speaker: VALIGNANO
dialogues.text: This letter came to us when you were traveling from Portugal. It took years to reach us. It was hidden, smuggled, ransomed and finally put into my hand by a Dutch trader. Who had other news as well.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: That he is alive?

dialogues.speaker: VALIGNANO
dialogues.text: That he apostatized. The young priests are stunned.

dialogues.speaker: VALIGNANO
dialogues.text: That he denounced God in public and surrendered the faith and is now living as a Japanese.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That’s not possible. (Father Ferreira risked his life to spread our faith all over Japan. We are here today because of him.)

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: He was the strongest of us.

dialogues.speaker: VALIGNANO
dialogues.text: He wrote those words during the most sweeping persecution of all. Now things are even worse. Thousands are dead for what we brought them. Thousands more have given up the faith.

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: You said this trader brought news. But it’s not proven, is it? It could be a slander created to further discredit our faith.

dialogues.speaker: VALIGNANO
dialogues.text: Given the extent of the persecution in that country...

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: Yes, Father, respectfully. There must be multitudes there who need us too.

dialogues.speaker: VALIGNANO
dialogues.text: (more emphatically now) ...and the fact there has been no other word of him, and the news brought by the Dutchman...

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: Rumor, Father, only... Rodrigues gestures to Garupe to moderate his tone as Vali fixes him with a look of stern impatience. Garupe lowers head in apology.

dialogues.speaker: VALIGNANO
dialogues.text: ..-I must conclude it is true.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: If it is true, Father, what would it mean for the Society? For our faith? For all of Catholic Europe? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RODRIGUES (cont'd) Father, it seems our mission here is more urgent than ever. We must find Father Ferreira.

dialogues.speaker: VALIGNANO
dialogues.text: I cannot allow that.

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: But you can’t allow us to abandon our mission.

dialogues.speaker: VALIGNANO
dialogues.text: Your mission was to find word of Ferreira. You have found it. Take this letter with you and return to Portugal.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Father, but the letter relates a terrible history. It says nothing about Ferreira himself. Whatever happened to him is still unknown. All we know of his fate is a slander. Permit me, Father Valignano, but I believe our mission still stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valignano walks with the young priests down the steps of cathedral. The great cathedral looms behind them. Fog han the air like clumps of cotton. Outlines of ships in the h can be seen in the distance; occasionally a MAST breaks t the fog, swaying with the roll of the tide, then disappea again.

dialogues.speaker: VALIGNANO
dialogues.text: If I permit you to go on to Japan, I'd be condemning you. This Inquisitor... this Inoue...he is terror itself. He may not be the devil, but he is just as cunning. And he was baptized. (beat) By me, during my ministry. Do you know how many Christians the authorities executed at Shimabara? Thousands. Tens of thousands. Most beheaded.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Each a martyr.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We must honor their memory and ask for their prayers. And we cannot abandon whoever remains. Valignano is wavering, swayed by the passion and idealism the young men. And they know that.

dialogues.speaker: VALIGNANO
dialogues.text: (a beat; then...) No, any missionary work in Japan, of any kind, is now out of the question for us. The only European ships permitted to enter port in Japan are Dutch.

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: Can the Dutch...

dialogues.speaker: VALIGNANO
dialogues.text: The Dutch are heretics. Religion is just a business advantage to them. No, it is far too dangerous for you.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: But how can we neglect a man who nurtured us in the faith? He shaped the world for us. (ALT1: He showed us our calling.) (ALT2: HE formed us as Jesuits.)

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: And even if this slander should be true, then Father Ferreira is damned.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: And we have no choice but to save his soul, Father.

dialogues.speaker: VALIGNANO
dialogues.text: This is in your hearts, then? Both of you?

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: It is. Like our first fervor. (ALT: Like our first fervor we felt in the novitiate. We feel it is a call, Father. )

dialogues.speaker: VALIGNANO
dialogues.text: Then I must trust God has put it there. He calls you to a great trial. From the moment you set foot in that country you step into high danger. (beat) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VALIGNANO (cont'd) You will be the last to go, you know. An army of two.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Two to find one. “Satis est, domine, satis est." (Our Saint Francis Xavier’s own words, Father.) “It is enough.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rodrigues and Garupe walk briskly past the crowded docks island waterfront. A misty rain falls. Junks are so close moored that their hulls make a scraping, thumping SOUND, muffled cadence. The Europeans take broad strides: the length of their ste their height, makes the Chinese population clogging the s and congregating around the wharves give way before them. CHINESE BUSINESSMAN has to almost trot to keep up.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “May 25, 1640. Pax Christi. God be praised. Father Valignano, as I begin these lines I cannot be sure that, when they are done, they will ever reach you.” The Chinese Businessman bustles ahead of the priests and gestures for them to follow him down a narrow alley.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “But I want to maintain your confidence in our mission, and vindicate your faith in us.” The Chinese Businessman stands at the entrance to a TAVER gesturing for the Priests to step inside. Rodrigues enter first, with Garupe close behind him.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “Today there was wonderful news. Your Mr. Chun got us a boat, with twenty- five Chinese sailors. And he found us a guide. Our first Japanese.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Chinese Businessman hovers in the background, the priests stoop to fit into this dank, low place. Seamen an traders drink steadily at rough tables. Others pass by wi women, who seem to be holding them up as they pass throug shadows. There is a MOAN from the corner of the room.

dialogues.speaker: CHINESE BUSINESSMAN
dialogues.text: He is not much. You will see. There is another MOAN. The Chinese Businessman bolts forw and plunges into this heap of shadows... ..+-pulling the body of a MAN (KICHIJIRO) into the feeble The disbelieving priests stare at the heap of humanity ly before them. He is their age, ragged and rough-skinned. CHINESE BUSINESSMAN (cont'd) But after almost two months, he is the only one.

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: Are you Japanese?

dialogues.speaker: CHINESE BUSINESSMAN
dialogues.text: Yes yes. He was drifting on sea. Portuguese bring him.

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: Are you really Japanese?

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Where are you from? Kichijiro crawls back into the comfort of the shadows. Th Chinese Businessman stops him with a kick. Kichijiro turn him, groaning incoherently. The Chinese Businessman takes prudent step back.

dialogues.speaker: CHINESE BUSINESSMAN
dialogues.text: Answer them, you fool! These are padres! (no response) Kichijiro! You fool! They will take you home.

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: Where is your home?

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: Nagasaki.  10

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: What’s your work?

dialogues.speaker: CHINESE BUSINESSMAN
dialogues.text: He will do what you say.

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: Fisherman.

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: Nagasaki is on Kyushu. (Kichijiro eyes him suspiciously) Can you tell us about Kyushu?

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: You know our language.

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: Little.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: You learned it from the Jesuit padres. You had to. So you are a Christian.

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: No. No Kirishitan. Kichijiro belches and shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: CHINESE BUSINESSMAN
dialogues.text: Good guide for you. And he is Christian too.

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: (snarls) I am not Kirishitan.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: You can tell us.

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: Kirishitan die. (beat) They die in Nagasaki.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: (to Kichijiro) Listen to me. We have money. Help us and we can take you home. We can... Kichijiro abruptly INTERRUPTS Rodrigues, HURLING himself feet of the surprised priests. He grovels, weeping.  11

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: I want to go home. Not for money. Japan is the country of my family. Please! Take me please! I beg you! Don’t abandon me here! The Chinese Businessman stares at the abject Kichijiro. Rodrigues nods his head slightly in silent assent and Kic immediately prostrates himself in drunken thanks. The Chi Businessman helps Kichijiro up to leave.

dialogues.speaker: CHINESE BUSINESSMAN
dialogues.text: You see. He will be very good guide. He will be good. As they make their way out, Kichijiro falls drunk onto a knocking into a man (Chinese? Portuguese?). The man pushe Kichijiro away. Kichijiro tries to stand up when he is pu again (attacked?). He cowers and begs. Rodrigues and Garu react. The Chinese Businessman tries to protect them. Rod and Garupe go to Kichijiro on the floor to stop the viole They help him up and hand him to the Chinese Businessman.

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: Our guide. He can’t be a Christian.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: He says he’s not but can you believe anything he says? The Chinese Businessman takes Kichijiro away down the all the taverners laugh.

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: I don’t even want to believe he’s Japanese.

dialogues.speaker: CHINESE BUSINESSMAN
dialogues.text: (shouting back to priests) You see. He will be good! The priests look at Kichijiro.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "And he said to them: Go ye into the whole world, and preach the gospel to every creature." Even to one such as this.” As the priests watch him, wondering if they'll regret the decision.  11 12 13 12

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So our Lord commanded. And as I prepare to do His work, I see His face before me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rodrigues lies on his simple bed, staring at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “His face is fresh in my memory. Just as I saw it the first time as a novice in Evora. He looks as he must have when He commanded Peter, ‘Feed my lambs, feed my lambs, feed my sheep.’ ”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU: The face of Christ in the image that Rodrigues rememb

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “It's a face filled with vigor and strength. It fascinates me. I feel such great love for it. ” From the face of Christ, we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...the face of Valignano, standing on the dock in a misty surreptitiously giving a blessing. A tender boat carrying two priests, now disguised as Chinese sailors, moves towa sea-battered Chinese junk waiting beyond the harbor.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “During the long weeks at sea the gift of God’s trust sustained us both. We never doubted His guiding hand. I embraced this journey as I embraced my vocation, with honest apprehension about my own strength, but with joy, too, that God has trusted me with this chance.”  14 15

dialogues.speaker: 15A
dialogues.text: 16 17 18 13 On the tender, the priests watch the figure of Valignano into the SWIRLING MIST like a daub of paint into a fresco

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE FIRST SIGHT OF LAND. A dramatic image of land but hig stylized to see the ominous nature of the landscape: a da outline, as if slashed with a calligrapher’s pen against last light of the sun. Mountains like sawtooths rising to darkening sky, narrow beaches that look like primeval roc gardens, thick stands of trees blotting out the horizon. place of threat and trial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIME CUT: Rodrigues and Garupe on the deck.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: It looks like the edge of the earth. A TINY BIRD ALIGHTS on the deck, near where Kichijiro is standing, studying the horizon line. Kichijiro looks out smiles?).

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: ...dapan...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On extreme close-up of Kichijiro's foot SPLASHING INTO th water. He STUMBLES in the shallow water near shore, brief submerging in the chill current, which is thick with twig Rodrigues and Garupe watch uneasily from the tender as Kichijiro surfaces and LURCHES toward the land.

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: We have trusted that man with our lives.  19 14

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Jesus trusted even worse. And he lowers himself over the side, into the water. Garu hesitates, then follows and they both make for the shore. And now we see where we are. The tender is near the shore Tomogi as the Chinese Junk stays at a distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Garupe and Rodrigues come ashore, Kichijiro GESTURES f them to hurry. They scurry forward toward a hollow rock l animals being pursued by hunters they can only sense. As as they reach shelter, Kichijiro is gone. It startles the

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: Kichijiro! Kichijiro! He’s gone to betray us. Their fear increases at the SOUND of something moving acr the rocky beach. Footsteps. Drawing closer. They huddle together, caked with soggy sand and dirt, a couple of landlocked sea rats.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: “Quod facis, fac citius.” “What you will do, do quickly.” Rodrigues and Garupe press themselves deep in the shadows the rock. Rodrigues is shivering. His teeth are CHATTERIN Garupe reaches for his companion and holds his head again chest, trying to MUFFLE the sound.

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: (fearfully) "A band of soldiers went there with lanterns and torches and weapons." The priests duck back behind their meager shelter as... ...a LIGHT FLARES suddenly just in front of them. The sound of feet, close now. And VOICES. The priests exc a FRIGHTENED GLANCE, then turn to see... ...the craggy, glowering face of an OLD MAN, looming over His very lack of expression is menacing. He studies them moment. A long, agonizing moment.  15

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN, (ICHIZO)
dialogues.text: Padre... The priests are stunned to hear this word in their langua The old man makes the sign of the cross. Tentatively, trembling, Garupe blesses him.

dialogues.speaker: ICHIZO
dialogues.text: Hurry. There is no time. They SCRAMBLE to their feet as a group of a dozen village carrying torches, surround them.

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: What is this place?

dialogues.speaker: ICHIZO
dialogues.text: Tomogi village.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Japan?

dialogues.speaker: ICHIZO
dialogues.text: (nods agreement) Please. Be quick. So gentios cannot see you.

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: Gentios? The villagers swarm over the priests, rapidly covering th with field hats and farmers’ overgarments. In their midst Kichijiro smiles at them with servile pride.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: (looking at Kichijiro) The way of the Lord surpasses all understanding. With Kichijiro always near, the villagers form a protecti phalanx as they guide them off the beach.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "‘Padre.’ ‘Gentios.’ Our own words sounded so foreign here. But they were a sign that the seed of our faith has been sown, and survives with tenacity. Now it is our mission to tend and nurture it, lest it wither and die.”  20 21 16 ..-Rodrigues and Garupe exchange a look as they are hurri inland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now away from the beach, Ichizo deliberately steps off th path and thrashes his way through the woods. The others f The priests stumble, trying to keep up. The going is hard villagers don't give a moment to rest. They press on, har

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “We were hurried to shelter because our Christians feared betrayal by those who had not embraced the faith. Gentiles, they called them. Although nearly all the two hundred families of Tomogi had been baptized, many fell under fear of the Inquisitor Inoue.” A villager hands Kichijiro a bottle of local rice wine (nigorizake), from which he takes liberal swigs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group comes out of the woods on a plateau just above village. Like haystacks in a rocky field, huts now loom c before them. They move stealthily along this back way tow the village. A man called MOKICHI draws even with them.

dialogues.speaker: ICHIZO
dialogues.text: Tomogi... our village... I’m sorry Padre, for this way... it is difficult. But too dangerous. There are more executions than ever.

dialogues.speaker: MOKICHI
dialogues.text: If they know we are Kirishitan we will be killed.

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: The Lord hears you.

dialogues.speaker: ICHIZO
dialogues.text: (humbly) Yes. He sent you to us.  22 17 They reach a hut, indistinguishable to the priests from t others dotting the ground. Ichizo nods for them to enter.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. ICHIZO’S HUT NIGHT 22 ICHIZO'S WIFE comes out of the shadows and kisses Garupe’ hand, startling him.

dialogues.speaker: ICHIZO
dialogues.text: We have a little food. If you would like.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Yes, please. Ichizo nods to her, and she leaves.

dialogues.speaker: MOKICHI
dialogues.text: You'll be safe here until morning.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Thank you. Tell me... (as he looks around) .--how do you live like this? The villagers look at him blankly. He thinks he may have misunderstood. Or, worse, may have insulted them.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I mean...how do you live as Christians, when the danger is so great?

dialogues.speaker: MOKICHI
dialogues.text: We pray in secret. But we have our jiisama...

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: (trying to say the word) Jiis -

dialogues.speaker: MOKICHI
dialogues.text: Jiisama. He leads us.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Who is this... (struggles with the word) .--Jjiisama? Mokichi NODS at Ichizo, who bows his head modestly.  18

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: .-+-he leads you? In your devotions?

dialogues.speaker: MOKICHI
dialogues.text: He prays with us. 22A INT. ICHIZO’S HUT NIGHT 22A On that last word, we CUT AWAY to brief images of Ichizo conducting a baptism.

dialogues.speaker: MOKICHI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The only sacrament he can perform is baptism. We worship with the jiisama. We hide the Kirishitan images but God still sees us, yes? Even though we do not have a priest? Until now.

dialogues.speaker: 22B OMITTED 22B
dialogues.text: 22C INT. ICHIZO’S HUT NIGHT 22C Ichizo's Wife quietly returns and HANDS each of the pries small bowl containing a few scrawny vegetables. They star eat. Mokichi MURMURS A QUICK grace. The priests are surpr And a little embarrassed to have forgotten the blessing. Rodrigues puts his bowl down.

dialogues.speaker: MOKICHI
dialogues.text: Every Kirishitan here is part of our secret church.The tossama guide us with prayer and teaching. The mideshi help the tossama to preserve the faith.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: I would like to meet the tossama.

dialogues.speaker: ICHIZO
dialogues.text: (nods at Mokichi) It is a group. And Mokichi is one of them. Mokichi lowers his eyes modestly.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: There was one of us, a priest, a padre, named Ferreira. Do you know of him?  19 The villagers shake their heads. The priests exchange a q look of disappointment, Suddenly Ichizo's Wife, who has been watching the Western eat, LAUGHS at Garupe’s way with the food. He smiles at h

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: (smiles, embarrassed) Did I do something wrong? I’m sorry. The expression of puzzlement on his face makes her laugh Rodrigues attempts to smooth over the awkwardness.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: All this...this faith you have...this courage...is only in Tomogi? What about other villages? Is it the same?

dialogues.speaker: ICHIZO
dialogues.text: We do not know about other villages. We never go there.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: You don’t go?

dialogues.speaker: ICHIZO
dialogues.text: Other villages are so dangerous. You don’t know who to trust. Everyone fears the Inquisitor, Inoue Sama.

dialogues.speaker: MOKICHI
dialogues.text: Anyone can expose you to the men of power. Inform on a Kirishitan and they give you one hundred pieces of silver.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Pieces of silver...

dialogues.speaker: ICHIZO
dialogues.text: Two hundred for a Kirishitan brother. And, for a priest, three hundred.

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: (disturbed) Three hundred? I’m flattered.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: You should go to the other villages, let them know priests are here again. In Japan again. That would be good. You must let them know.  23 20 Ichizo nods polite agreement, but Rodrigues can see he ha persuaded him. It is as he reaches for his meager bowl of again that he notices Ichizo has not been eating.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: (to Ichizo) You do not eat?

dialogues.speaker: ICHIZO
dialogues.text: It is you who feed us. Rodrigues is struck by the simplicity and force of the an As he bends over his bowl, his NECKLACE WITH A CRUCIFIX ATTACHED SWINGS FREE across his chest. Mokichi sees it. His eyes fill with a flash of emotion an hands make an involuntary movement toward the crucifix. Rodrigues understands. SERIES OF QUICK DISSOLVES: TO the crucifix, pressed to th forehead of Mokichi, who is kneeling before Rodrigues; TO Garupe, offering his own crucifix to Ichizo; TO the old m hands, wrapped around Garupe's; TO Mokichi's hands, as he the cross Rodrigues offers.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (over series of dissolves) “I was overwhelmed right away by the love I felt from these people, even though their faces couldn't show it. They cannot reveal sorrow or joy. Long years of secrecy have made their faces into masks.” Mokichi KISSES the cross and hangs it around his neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SERIES OF FACES in the procession, walking and staring straight ahead. Mokichi. Ichizo. Other villagers. Faces s to be impassive. Garupe and Rodrigues, now dressed entirely in peasant clo are following them with difficulty over the rough terrain Patches of thick wet mist swirl and drift all around them

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “They do not dare take us anywhere by the main road. To hide like this must be a terrible burden. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 24 25 21 RODRIGUES (V.O.) (cont'd) Why do they have to suffer so much? Why did God pick them to bear such a burden? END series of CUs and CUT BACK to the procession...climbi through the woods...seen now from a distance, a ragged or small, brittle figures in an engulfing landscape.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “I pray Garupe and I have the strength to help them.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tumbledown charcoal storage hut near the top of the mou The last of the morning mist is just burning off, but the beauty of the landscape only seems to underscore the seve the desolation--of this pathetic shelter.

dialogues.speaker: MOKICHI
dialogues.text: This is safest here.

dialogues.speaker: ICHIZO
dialogues.text: If you are found, we will all be killed. When you hear this sound... ..-he makes a WRAPPING SIGNAL on the door.

dialogues.speaker: ICHIZO
dialogues.text: ..-it will be us. If you hear anything else... On the loud OVERLAPPING SOUND of boards being dropped we.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mokichi and two of the other villagers toss slatted board aside to reveal a deep hole in the ground. Dust and dirt in the air.

dialogues.speaker: ICHIZO
dialogues.text: Hide.

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: It looks like a grave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Rodrigues teaches a catechism lesson to TOMOGI VILLAGE VILLAGE WOMAN sinks to her knees before Garupe. Garupe LE close to her, then backs off. He checks himself, and stay close as she turns her face up to him. His face betrays t of distaste that his piety and earnestness cannot quite h

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: (heavy accent) Konhisan, Padre. Please.

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: Of course I'll...if I knew...what is it? (struggling) Kocha? Kosha?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Konhisan. The young priest looks at her blankly. She begins on her

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: "Bless me, Father, for I have sinned..." And now he understands: confession. He makes a belated bl as she continues to speak and we hear...

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “We quickly settled into a routine. Hearing confession, and forgiving sins, even though we could not always be sure what was being confessed.” A moth flies round and round an oil lamp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another day. Ichizo's hand REACHES for a thin straw mat o floor, RAISES it as if there is something underneath. The nothing. But the hand starts to separate the mat.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “Their old faith offered resignation and a road that ended in darkness. Christianity brought love, and life everlasting. And we see there are two layers of mat, one against the o As Ichizo separates them we see a hidden paper.  23

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “The dignity for the first time of being treated like God’s creatures, not animals. And the promise that earthly trial would not end in nothingness, but in salvation.” Ichizo SMOOTHS the wrinkled paper and passes it reverentl Rodrigues, who nods and PASSES it to Garupe. It is a pict Jesus (or Mary). He places it on a low table against the serving as an altar upon which are placed a chalice, pate missal, water and wine. A light has been lit.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “Images of Our Lord and the Blessed Virgin Mary sustain them. So they can see past the image, and find God in their own hearts, we give religious instruction and teach new prayers. Quietly” Rodrigues TURNS: faithful of the village crowd this hut. villagers stare at the picture of Jesus (or Mary) in awe make gestures of great reverence. Rodrigues makes the sig the cross and begins Mass.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: In nomine Patris, et Filii, et Spiritus Sancti, Amen. Introibo ad altare Dei.... Kichijiro stands in the back, not quite sober, watching.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “We offer Mass in the dead of night, just as they did in the Catacombs. But in whispers. And when morning comes we leave the village...quietly...still with no word of Ferreira.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garupe and Rodrigues negotiate the rough path through the forest as Mokichi clears the way just ahead of them.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “,..and we climb the mountain again. And wait. And hide. These people carry the burden of their faith up this steep road more easily than we do. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 29 24 RODRIGUES (V.O.) (cont'd) Their trust in us is total, and we have to be careful they do not give us too much. When I asked Ichizo's wife for food that first day, she gave us almost all they had. They hurry out of the woods toward the sheltering outline their hut, visible ahead in billowing clouds of early-mor mist.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “The love of all these people overwhelms us both.””

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rodrigues is BAPTIZING a baby held by its mother as the f looks on with a mixture of pride and wariness. He holds t only instrument for the ceremony - a broken little peasan cup used for holy water.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: “Paatere to, Hiiriyo to, Supiritsu Santo no mina o motte soregashi nanji o araitatematsuru. Amen.”

dialogues.speaker: WIFE
dialogues.text: We now? All with God, in paraiso?

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: (frustrated) Paradise? Now? No. But God is there now, and forever. He prepares a place for us all. Even now. The husband and wife give no sign of comprehending, but t bow and leave, passing Ichizo's Wife standing patiently h two meager bowls of food.

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: Blessed be God. (beat) Arigataya. She BOWS and exits. Garupe HANDS Rodrigues a bowl of food

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Sebastiado, for my impatience. I’m ashamed of my frustration.  30 25 Rodrigues NODS his head in understanding.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: The child is safe in God's grace. That's what’s important. Both priests bow their heads over the food in silent bles then start to eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heavy RAIN pelts the charcoal hut, running off the straw in great streams and LEAKING inside. Garupe and Rodrigues PICKING lice off their clothes using their fingers as twe Garupe mutters something under his breath.

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: “Joy of my heart.”

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: “We shall never find another race to equal the Japanese. They are the joy of my heart.” Our Saint Francis Xavier’s words. He must not have come across any lice. The only way we can win against these things is to get out of here. Rodrigues tweezes several small white lice with his finge Frustrated, Garupe picks up a rock and pounds at them. GARUPE (cont'd) (pummeling the lice) I'm sorry. I know that's weak. (WHACK! )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But all I feel for these people is pity, not love.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: I know. I feel pity too. (beat) Our Saint Francis also told us to render an account first to God, then to our own conscience. Then we can do much good for our neighbors.  26

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: Do you think we have? Done good?

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Yes I do. Of course I do.

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: Much good? Rodrigues wipes his hands and passes Garupe a small bowl roots and pumpkin scraps.

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: It's just that these people are so frightened. Is fear all they have? (WHACK! )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And lice?

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: They have us. We comfort them.

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: How much longer can we do that?

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: We asked for this mission, Francisco. We begged Father Valignano for it. We prayed for it in the Exercises. God heard us then, He hears us still.

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: Then may He guide us to Ferreira. So we can know the truth.

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: The truth.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Do you think there’s any doubt?

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: You think his strength gave out and he groveled in front of the Inquisitor Inoue? Went on his knees like a dog?  31 27

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: That’s still just a rumor. Even if this Inoue is the devil everyone claims, Ferreira would stand up to him.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: You don’t seem so certain, Francisco. (no reply from Garupe) One of us has to go to Nagasaki and find him.

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: It’s too dangerous. If we’re caught there will be terrible reprisals to the people who shelter us.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Then Kichijiro can go and bring back word we can act on.

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: Are you mad? Where is he? Kichijiro’s never sober. You know he can’t be trusted.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: So we stay here like this? No. We must do something to find Father Ferreira. Garupe bangs his food bowl down on another swarm of lice.

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: Yes. Of course. But first I have to find all these lice. The SOUND of the rock echoes through the hut as Garupe continues to attack the lice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few hours later. Beams of straggling SUNLIGHT creep ben the door.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Let’s go out. Let’s risk it. Just for a moment.  32 28 Garupe looks up from making little crosses out of wood splinters and pieces of straw as Rodrigues opens the door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ground outside the hut is wet with just-fallen rain. Rodrigues sees clear water dripping from bright green lea He turns his face to the sunlight piercing the mist. Garu seated beside him on a rock. Rodrigues notices a BIRD, SOARING through the shafts of sunlight over Garupe's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: There. Look. I'm sure it's the same bird. We see the bird, FLOATING free in the light wind.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The one from the ship. It watches over us. Garupe turns his head to watch the bird...

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It’s God's sign. «-.-Still in flight but nearing the ground, flying past.. ...-TWO MEN, apparitional figures in the still-thick mist Standing, staring. Unmoving. Garupe SEES them first. He reaches for Rodrigues’s arm.

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: Don’t move. Someone’s here. Watching us. Rodrigues follows his gaze, SEES the two men shrouded in distant mist. He doesn’t move a muscle. Until...the mist and OBSCURES the figures.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Now! The priests DASH for the safety of the charcoal hut and..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...their hiding place in the floor. They RIP the floor bo up, squeezing themselves into the deep darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hours later. The land looks peaceful under a full moon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The priests are now coiled tensely in their hiding place. soft sound of a VOICE pierces the quiet.

dialogues.speaker: GOTO MAN 1, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Padre... The Priests start to panic.

dialogues.speaker: GOTO MAN 1, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (a little louder now) Padre. Rodrigues starts to get out of the hiding place.

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: No! It’s not the signal! The door creaks...

dialogues.speaker: GOTO MAN 1, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Padre, do not be afraid, it’s all right. We won’t hurt you. We’re Kirishitan, Padre. Kirishitan. Rodrigues and Garupe wait. They hear footsteps walk away. Rodrigues wrenches free. He hoists himself out of the hid place, goes to the door and opens it. He sees TWO MEN prostrating themselves before him on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: GOTO MAN 2
dialogues.text: We frightened you. We are sorry. (As Rodrigues collects himself) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 36 30 GOTO MAN 2 (cont'd) We want to ask you to come to our village. To Goto. People miss our faith there. Our children need you. We have no Mass, no confession. The Goto Men watch them eagerly. One of the men has blood from climbing the mountain to the hut.

dialogues.speaker: GOTO MAN 1
dialogues.text: All we can do is pray. Rodrigues looks down at the Goto Man’s bloody feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rodrigues carefully bathes and bandages the Goto Man’s bl feet as Garupe questions them.

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: How did you know we were here? The Goto Men lower their eyes.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: It’s all right. You can tell us. Was it one of the faithful?

dialogues.speaker: GOTO MAN 2
dialogues.text: It was a Kirishitan of our village. Kichijiro.

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: (stunned) Kichijiro? Our Kichijiro?

dialogues.speaker: GOTO MAN 1
dialogues.text: He says he came here with you.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: But he is not a Christian.

dialogues.speaker: GOTO MAN 2
dialogues.text: Yes he is. It’s true, he spoke against God to the Inquisitor, Inoue Sama. But that was eight years ago. His whole family was put to death. He spoke against God. But he still believes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: High angle down on the tall green reeds WAVING AND RUSTLI VOICES raised in intense debate float in the thin air. Th from Goto stand aside respectfully, listening anxiously.

dialogues.speaker: MOKICHI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No, Padre...

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: But we will return here.

dialogues.speaker: ICHIZO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I don’t know the people of Goto, so I don’t know they can be trusted.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: They are Christians, just like us. Garupe and Rodrigues stand among the villagers who have s their work. Surrounded by the reeds, they look like creat at the bottom of a deep dry sea. They are troubled at the the two priests have just told them.

dialogues.speaker: MOKICHI
dialogues.text: Kichijiro told them to come here. I am not sure why. Why does he do anything?

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Kichijiro brought us to Tomogi.

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: It will be only for a few days. Deus commands us all to spread the gospel to every living creature.

dialogues.speaker: ICHIZO
dialogues.text: (beat) But one will stay. Here. Please.

dialogues.speaker: MOKICHI
dialogues.text: It is safer. There is much danger to travel together.

dialogues.speaker: ICHIZO
dialogues.text: And for us, too. Danger for all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rodrigues sails from the beach in a boat piloted by a sil BOATMAN. Garupe, Mokichi and Ichizo and a few other villa watch him move away into the GATHERING FOG. Rodrigues mak sign of the cross, but he is hardly filled with confidenc himself. The Boatman squints ahead into the fog, shadows from the lantern on the mast making his face look like a ghost mas Rodrigues SEES a second boat nearby, carrying the Goto me of them looks back at Rodrigues, his face expressionless. This makes Rodrigues even more uneasy as the second boat swallowed in the darkness like a ghost ship.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Boatman...we’re losing them. The Boatman doesn’t acknowledge him. Rodrigues says a sil prayer before his boat, too, vanishes in the gathering fo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A face suddenly appears in the fog. Then another. On the boat, Rodrigues recoils, startled, fearful, as... ...-FOUR VILLAGERS WADE into the BREAKING SURF on the bea surging toward the boat.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “Truly, on the journey I was full of fear..never more than when we landed on the island.” Four sets of hands CLUTCH at him. He thinks he is being captured...until one of the villagers makes the sign of t cross. Then another. And then all. Rodrigues is reassured. He lets himself be helped off the into the surf, towards the beach. The villagers stay clos him in the water, protecting him.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “But the joy which greeted me, I finally realized, was almost as great as my own, coming safely to that village. I thanked God for bringing me here.”  40 33 Another small group of villagers waits anxiously. As Rodr makes his way toward them, they part respectfully... .+-and Rodrigues sees Kichijiro in their midst, smiling l hero.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “Even the sight of Kichijiro was somehow welcome.” Rodrigues regards Kichijiro with a look of relief tempere wariness. In the distance, a dog HOWLS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a crumbling farmhouse, with a large congregation of villagers, Rodrigues celebrates Mass under a bright and cloudless sky. It is an occasion of reverence and joy.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “On that day, the faithful received fresh hope. I was renewed.” As the priest celebrates the Mass, consecrating the host, faces of the villagers -- even of Kichijiro -- reflect th power of this open demonstration of faith.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “Their lives here are so hard. They live like beasts and die like beasts.” Outside, villagers bringing the sick, infirm, children an babies to the priests form a broken line going back into hills. TIME CUT: Now Rodrigues distributes Holy Communion. He re he does not have hosts for the whole congregation and dec to break small particles from his own host to distribute. Villagers receive it with deep humility. Some even weep quietly.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “But Christ did not die for the good and beautiful. That is easy enough. The hard thing is to die for the miserable and corrupt. But here I knew I was one of them, and I shared the hunger of their spirit.”  4l 34 TIME CUT: Villagers continue to make their way to the far - the sick are carried. Rodrigues passes among the faithf with SMALL WOODEN CRUCIFIXES MADE FROM WOOD SPLINTERS; VERONICAS, small pendants with the image of Jesus; and OT DEVOTIONAL OBJECTS made of paper. Rodrigues takes his ros and unfastening the beads gives one to each until they ar gone. The Villagers REACH OUT FOR them eagerly - everyone is, but Kichijiro, who shrinks back.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “They are desperate for tangible signs of faith, so I provided what I could. I worry they value these poor signs of faith more than faith itself, but how could we deny them?” TIME CUT: Rodrigues distributes the last of the devotiona objects. But the villagers seem to expect more. They don’ to disperse.

dialogues.speaker: GOTO SICK MAN
dialogues.text: Padre. Listen to me. Konhisan. TIME CUT: Rodrigues looks out.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Now...will you say with me...the words of this prayer. He bows his head. The congregation follows.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: (in rough but determined Japanese) “Ten ni mashimasu warera ga on’oya, mina o tattomaretamae, miyo kitaritamae...” The congregation joins him in saying the prayer. EXT. GOTO CRUMBLING FARMHOUSE DAY 4l TIME CUT: After the prayer, Rodrigues walks among the fai

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “And they came to me. I felt God Himself was so near.” He STOPS and speaks with an OLD GOTO MAN.  42 35

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “One prayer was answered on Goto. It was there I learned the first real news of someone who might be Father Ferreira.”

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: You’ve seen him then. A stern man?

dialogues.speaker: GOTO MAN
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) Oh no. Kind. So they say. It’s said he made a place for infants and the sick at Shinmachi. But who can know for sure? That was before the trouble.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Where is that?

dialogues.speaker: GOTO MAN
dialogues.text: Near Nagasaki. But so dangerous to go. The Old Goto Man slips back into the crowd. Rodrigues’ fa shows a strange mixture of concern and excitement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA TRACKS through dense, quiet woods.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “In Goto I baptized over a hundred adults and children, heard confessions without number, gave instruction and celebrated Mass. But it was from Kichijiro that I felt the greatest need.” CAMERA NOW DISCOVERS: Kichijiro on his knees before Rodri in a clearing like a small Gethsemane.

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: I was Kirishitan. I am Kirishitan.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: You did not take the crucifix.

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: I did not deserve it.  43 44 45 36

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Because you denied God?

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: Yes, but only to live. Peter denied Him three times, and still Peter loved God. My whole family. They...we were betrayed by an informer. The Inquisitor Inoue wanted us to give up our faith. Stamp on Jesus with our foot. Just once, just fast. But they would not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close up of the fumie. A foot hovers over it, WAVERING. I board to which an iconic religious image has been attache this case an image on metal of Christ.

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But I did. Kichijiro's foot COMES DOWN on the fumie as his family wa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kichijiro becomes increasingly distraught as he speaks.

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: My brothers and sisters...our parents...were all put in prison. I was released. But I could not abandon them, even if I had abandoned God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Filled with samurai, guards, officials and the curious: a crowd has gathered to watch a familiar ritual.

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So I watched them die.  46 37 In the center of the surrounding crowd, Kichijiro's whole family--his mother and father, two brothers and two siste have been prepared for execution: his sister is bound to stake, another is tied to a stake, four are bundled in st sacks and piled on top of each other. They are lit on fir SMOKE fills the sky and FLAMES CONSUME the bodies of the prisoners, who SCREAM AND CRY to the heavens for mercy. One of Kichijiro's sisters has long hair, hanging loose. flames devour her body, they seem to rush up the hair, qu surrounding her head with what looks, for a brief, horrib moment, like a CROWN OF FIRE. In the crowd, Kichijiro, covered with filth and looking l wild dog, TURNS AWAY from this horror and tries to run. B legs won't support him. He FALLS to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Whatever I do, wherever I go, I see the fire and smell the flesh. The one thing more terrible to me than their dying is my shame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kichijiro is close to tears.

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: After I saw you and Padre Garupe for the first time...I thought...I started to believe...that God might take me back. Because in...in my dreams, the fire was no longer so bright. Rodrigues looks at him very closely: he wants to believe testament, but he is still skeptical.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Jesus said, "Every one therefore that shall confess me before men, I will also confess him before my Father who is in heaven. But he that shall deny me before men, I will also deny him before my Father who is in heaven." Kichijiro, chastened, lowers his head.  47 38

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: (beat; then relenting) Do you want me to hear your confession now?

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: (in tears) Bless me, Father, for I have sinned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Boatman is taking Rodrigues and Kichijiro back to Tom Kichijiro sprawls against the side of the boat.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “Confession may have been good for Kichijiro’s soul, but I admit, Father, it did not do much for his thirst.” Kichijiro salutes Rodrigues with a bottle of rice wine (doburoku) as he takes a long gulp.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “But still those six days at Goto, and Kichijiro’s renewal of faith, made me think I could really be of use to people in this country at the ends of the earth...a people and a country I could still never understand.”

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: A little strong drink once in a while might do you good, Padre. Have some?

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: You have a good heart, Kichijiro. You want to be a good man, all you need is strong faith.

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: I have faith, Padre. And thirst too. He holds the bottle out to Rodrigues again. Rodrigues considers...and takes a gulp. He looks off the bow and se they are approaching Tomogi beach.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: We're there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Following Kichijiro, who has gone ahead, Rodrigues DASHES the shelter of some overhanging rocks. Rodrigues HEARS a noise and, expecting Kichijiro, boldly from his shelter.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: You took so long I thought... But it’s Mokichi, with Kichijiro and a few other village behind him. They are anxious, and a few are afraid.

dialogues.speaker: MOKICHI
dialogues.text: Men. From the Inquisitor. They are in the village. They took Ichizo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From far away, and above. Midday sun pierces the sky, shi on a great CLOUD of WHITE DUST, making it almost gleam. T dust cloud obscures the village street. There is a SOUND, as of distant thunder...and A RIDERLESS GALLOPS through the cloud of dust and out of the village. From a hiding place on a hill just above the village, Rod and Garupe watch silently, fearfully. The dust cloud dissipates, revealing armed samurai moving inexorably forward. The samurai stare impassively ahead at the entire populat the village, assembled down the length of the dirt street trying to hide their fear. Expecting the worst. And the villagers look up at the sound of another horse.. one moving slowly. It carries the SAMURAI COMMANDER, who down at the villagers with level and chilling indifferenc Behind him is another rider, an OLD SAMURAI wearing a hug black hat like an umbrella. He smiles at the villagers benevolently. Behind him, roughneck GUARDS lead a prisoner on foot. The is tightly bound and pulled along harshly. It is Ichizo. The Samurai Commander reins in his horse in the middle of street. The guards bring Ichizo to stand beside him.  40

dialogues.speaker: SAMURAI COMMANDER
dialogues.text: (to the villagers) We _know there are Christians among you, like this poor wretch here. An informer told us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mokichi steps forward, a reluctant spokesman.

dialogues.speaker: MOKICHI
dialogues.text: But _we pay our taxes every year. And do our duty to the State. We worship in the temple like generations before us.

dialogues.speaker: SAMURAI COMMANDER
dialogues.text: We_know you’re all good people. We only want to hear about those who embrace the outlawed faith. And those who hide them. We will know who they are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Old Samurai looks benignly around at the terrified villagers. His presence is almost reassuring as his eyes over the people. From their hiding place on the hill, Rodrigues and Garupe everything that is happening with increasing unease.

dialogues.speaker: SAMURAI COMMANDER
dialogues.text: Think of the price for information. So much silver.

dialogues.speaker: OLD SAMURAI
dialogues.text: You_have three days. He slaps the reins easily on the horse's back. The horse him slowly down the main street as the people stare at hi Old Samurai seems to regret the treatment of Ichizo as mu they do. The Samurai Commander NODS once and his men undo Ichizo’s bonds.

dialogues.speaker: SAMURAI COMMANDER
dialogues.text: We will let this one go. But if we hear nothing in three days, we will take him again, along with three others. Choose them yourselves. (to Mokichi, casually) But_one of them must be you.

dialogues.speaker: MOKICHI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I am not afraid to die, padres.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hut is bursting with people from the village, all of in a state of worried agitation. Rodrigues and Garupe try calm them a little even as they grapple with their own fe MOKICHI (cont'd) And we will never surrender you. Rodrigues is shamed by the strength of this simple resolv

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: (quietly) No one should die.

dialogues.speaker: MOKICHI
dialogues.text: No, but we’ll be in danger whether you go or stay. So stay. Stay. We will never surrender you.

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: They'll keep coming back if we stay. They could destroy the entire village and kill you all while we hide.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: We should give ourselves up. That would draw the danger away from you. There is a movement at the door: Kichijiro stands there silhouetted against the inky sky and sparkling moonlight.

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: We can hide on his island.

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: (taken aback) There is no difference between there and here. They will come to Goto, they will search, the same thing will happen.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: And what would the people of Tomogi say if we ran?

dialogues.speaker: MOKICHI
dialogues.text: All would say we love God. And you. Even those who think Inoue Sama is trying to protect our country.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Protect it from what? Salvation?  42

dialogues.speaker: VILLAGER 1
dialogues.text: No! They would say it would be a good thing if you leave! More of us would be saved! Garupe and Rodrigues don’t understand what is being said, from the fact that it is spoken in Japanese--and so angri they know it does not bode well.

dialogues.speaker: VILLAGER 2
dialogues.text: You_can’t say that! They came to do God’s work. We can’t just give them up to Inoue’s tortures after all they have done for us.

dialogues.speaker: VILLAGER 1
dialogues.text: What have they done? They’ve put us all in danger! We never knew danger like this before they came here! Slowly Ichizo, who has taken no part in this debate, RAIS HAND. The room immediately goes quiet.

dialogues.speaker: ICHIZO
dialogues.text: The padres stay. He repeats what he just said for the two priests.

dialogues.speaker: ICHIZO
dialogues.text: You will stay. (a beat of silence) Now we must pick two more to join us. Who will be a hostage? Who will join me_and Mokichi to honor God? An embarrassed, uneasy silence descends as every man in t room tries to avoid the eyes of the others. Finally one m (HOSTAGE 3) STEPS FORWARD. But after him, no one else mov Until finally someone POINTS AT KICHIJIRO.

dialogues.speaker: TOMOGI HUSBAND
dialogues.text: He’s not from here. What about him?

dialogues.speaker: VILLAGER 2
dialogues.text: (to Kichijiro) Yes. For all our sakes. Please consider it. It won’t be so hard on you. The officials won’t question you so severely. It’s the people of Tomogi they want now.  43

dialogues.speaker: VILLAGER 1
dialogues.text: He’s_ not from here, why should we trust him? He could be the one who informed on us.

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: I’m not an informer! Tell them, Padre. (looking pleadingly at Rodrigues) I confessed all my sins.

dialogues.speaker: VILLAGER 2
dialogues.text: Then if you’ve received the Lord’s blessing act like it. Honor him with your life. Give us ours.

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: Honor? What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: VILLAGER 2
dialogues.text: A real Kirishitan would know!

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: Does_your mother know you?

dialogues.speaker: VILLAGER 2 KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: (overlapping) (overlapping) You_ can’t say things like I_can say what I want to you

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: that to me. A man from Tomogi you think I’m afraid of you doesn’t let himself be talked I’m not afraid of anyone. to like that by anyone, much less _a drunk from Goto. Villager 2 LUNGES angrily for the cowering Kichijiro. Oth villagers struggle to hold him back. The hut fills with a shouting.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Stop it! The Priests struggle to separate Kichijiro and the Villag they back away from one another, a VILLAGE WOMAN haltingl moves from the wall and prostrates herself in front of Kichijiro. He can’t look at her.

dialogues.speaker: VILLAGE WOMAN
dialogues.text: Please. Go _in our place. Silence in the room. Kichijiro looks over to Rodrigues. F guidance? For sympathy? He stares at the priest. Then NOD HEAD--ALMOST IMPERCEPTIBLY--IN ASSENT.  51 44

dialogues.speaker: MOKICHI
dialogues.text: So. The four of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A drizzle softens the summer air as the priests escort th villagers to the head of the trail that leads down the mo to the village.

dialogues.speaker: MOKICHI
dialogues.text: But if we are told...if they make us trample on our Lord... on the fumie...if it will save the others...

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: You must pray for courage, Mokichi.

dialogues.speaker: MOKICHI
dialogues.text: But if we do not do what they want, there can be danger for everyone in the village. They can be questioned, taken prisoner. Taken away forever. What should we do? The cicadas click relentlessly, their clicking sound carr the wind in the tall trees.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: (impulsively) It’s alright. Trample. It’s alright to trample... Rodrigues stops himself, realizing the full impact of wha just blurted out. The villagers seem similarly surprised Garupe looks at Rodrigues in reproachful astonishment.

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: What are you saying? You can’t...

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: Padre, why does Deusu give us such a terrible trial? We did not do anything wrong. Rodrigues collects himself and the two priests look at ea other. An even harder question with no easy answer. Or no answer at all. Except...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Priests and villagers KNEEL TOGETHER as a fine drizzle fa They are finishing a prayer. Rodrigues feels Mokichi take hand and PRESS something into it: a small hand-carved cro lovingly crafted, subtle and distinctive in its power. Rodrigues is deeply moved.

dialogues.speaker: MOKICHI
dialogues.text: Please. I made this for the jiisama. Before you came. It was all we had. But now we have so much more. From you. (Rodrigues shakes his head) I have another. The one you gave me. I will always have it. Take this. Please. In Jesus' name.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Your faith gives me strength, Mokichi. I wish I could give as much to you.

dialogues.speaker: MOKICHI
dialogues.text: My love for God is strong. Could that be the same as faith?

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: (moved) I think it must be. Mokichi FOLDS Rodrigues' fingers over the cross as we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SAMURAI COMMANDER, riding down the village street pas sullen, frightened populace. Behind him is Ichizo, tied a being PULLED ALONG by a GUARD on foot.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “These people are the most devoted of God's creatures on earth. Father Valignano, I confess, I began to wonder. God sends us trials to test us, and everything He does is good. And I prayed to undergo trials, like his Son. But why must their trial be so terrible? And why, when I look in my own heart, do the answers I give them seem so weak?”  46 Behind Ichizo we see the three other hostages: Mokichi an Kichijiro

dialogues.speaker: TIME CUT
dialogues.text: and Hostage 3, all tied and pulled along.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “They were in prison for three days. We prayed for their safe return, hoping then we might be safe too.” The Samurai Commander turns to address the hostages.

dialogues.speaker: SAMURAI COMMANDER
dialogues.text: You all know that Christianity is an outlawed religion.

dialogues.speaker: MOKICHI
dialogues.text: We_know that. But we are Buddhists. We live according to the teachings of the priests at our Temple.

dialogues.speaker: SAMURAI COMMANDER
dialogues.text: Is_ that so? All of you? (they nod slowly) Then it will be an easy thing to step on the image of the Blessed Virgin and her child. Fume! One by one, they begin to obey the order. XCU: of feet an knees, FALLING on the image of Christ.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “All of them did as they were commanded. But it was not enough.” The Samurai Commander looks at them with contempt.

dialogues.speaker: SAMURAI COMMANDER
dialogues.text: You think we’re fooled so easily? We saw _how you looked as your foot came down. You were nervous. Full of fear. From the hiding place on the hill above the village Rodri and Garupe watch the events below with mounting dread.

dialogues.speaker: MOKICHI
dialogues.text: We_were not. Why should we be? We’re Buddhists.

dialogues.speaker: SAMURAI COMMANDER
dialogues.text: Then let’s try one more way. He holds up a crucifix.  54 55 47 SAMURAI COMMANDER (cont'd) Spit on this. And say your so-called Blessed Virgin is a whore. CU: Ichizo, with a crucifix held close to his face by an outstretched hand. The old man SHAKES HIS HEAD.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Old Ichizo would not do it. XCU: an eye, as a TEAR ROLLS down the face of Mokichi.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Mokichi could not. Neither could the other man. But Kichijiro succeeded where the rest failed. Kichijiro SPITS on the crucifix. Then he is PULLED roughl his feet by two guards and shoved away. Kichijiro runs of shame.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And so he was released. I must believe he suffered, along with the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three trees made into the shape of crosses stand at the w edge, stark against the sky. Ichizo, Mokichi and Hostage tied to the crosses by Guards. One offers them some sake warm themselves.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “We were told they were given sake, as the Roman soldier offered vinegar to the dying Christ. Garupe and Rodrigues WATCH from a hiding place in the roc RODRIGUES (V.O.) (Cont'd) “Perhaps they remembered our Lord’s suffering and took courage and comfort from it.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WAVES BREAK on the beach at the head of an onrushing tide SWAMPING the crucified Mokichi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 56 48 His body is crusted with salt, twisted by the rush of the water. He TWISTS in agony. Next to him is the body of Hos 3, who has already died.

dialogues.speaker: MOKICHI
dialogues.text: Deusu...Deusu... On his right, Ichizo's aged body spasms in pain. He too i dying. He looks over at Mokichi and manages to say one wo

dialogues.speaker: ICHIZO
dialogues.text: Pa...paraiso. And dies. Mokichi averts his eyes and raises them to heav

dialogues.speaker: MOKICHI
dialogues.text: Deusu, receive his spirit. Now his suffering is ended, receive him, Lord in Your glory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another WAVE STRIKES him in the face.

dialogues.speaker: MOKICHI
dialogues.text: Please Jesus!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOURS LATER: The waves have subsided. Guards sit on rocks listening to someone singing. It is Mokichi, singing a hy Rodrigues and Garupe listen from their hiding place. A mo of grace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As before: camera sweeps along with an incoming WAVE BREA against the shore, the water rushing up the sand toward.. .+-Mokichi, on the cross. The tide is not quite so high n hits him chest level. But his body hangs limp and lifeles the cross. The pull of the tide has already torn him from ropes that bind him. His body DANGLES loose. Another wave buffets Mokichi's body and finally BREAKS IT from the cross. His body is TOSSED in the water.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “It took Mokichi four days to die. At the end he sang a hymn, so they say. His voice was the only sound. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 57 49 RODRIGUES (V.O.) (cont'd) The people of the village who were gathered on the beach were always silent.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guards GRAB Mokichi’s body by his arms and carry him up t beach, under the watchful supervision of the samurai.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “The people were watched closely, so the bodies could not be given a Christian burial.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Instructed by the samurai, Guards FLING Mokichi's body on pyre made of driftwood.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “Mokichi’s body was so heavy with water it turned the flames to smoke before it finally caught fire. Any bones that remained were scattered in the ocean, so they could not be venerated.” Through the smoking, leaping flames WE SEE: the three cro still planted firm in the moonlit sand.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “I had long read about martyrdom in The Lives of the Saints, but this was no such glorious thing. Surely God heard their prayers as they died. But did He hear their screams? I prayed that He might reach out to them, but how can I explain His silence to these people who have endured so much? I need all my strength to understand it myself. Humanity is so sad, Lord, and the ocean so blue.” From their hiding place, Rodrigues and Garupe pray silent the three empty crosses are washed with sea water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rodrigues and Garupe, accompanied by several anxious vill HURRY toward two waiting fishing boats.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “This may be my last report to you, Father. Today we hear the guards are in the mountains looking for us. So we have decided it will be safer to separate. Father Garupe will make for Hirado, to continue the mission, and I will return to Goto to try to learn more about Shinmachi. The last place Father Ferreira lived, and the place I may still find him. Please believe, Father, that if these are my last words to you I ask forgiveness for my weakness and my doubt, and I beg God for the strength to stand against whatever suffering befalls me if Inoue finds me. And I ask you to remember Father Garupe and me in your Masses and in your prayers. With my life and whole heart, I praise God. Remember us in your holy sacrifices, your obedient son...” They have to tear their glance away from the crosses, whi stand like giant driftwood in the drift of the sea.

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: Kichijiro was right. If we’d left they might still be alive.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: We don’t know that. And we can’t doubt. That will be our death.

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: Are we giving up? Is that what we’re doing? Are we running away?

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: It’s more of a test than we thought.

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: After people have died for us. I feel like a coward.  51

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: No. Our purpose is the same. We can’t fulfill it if we’re captured. God will give us strength. Garupe REACHES inside his clothes and removes his rosary. offers it to Rodrigues.

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: Take this. Remember me.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Thank you, brother. But I have this. Rodrigues shows him the carved cross that Mokichi gave hi

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: From one of our blessed martyrs already in heaven. (Garupe looks doubtful) Because of us, Francisco. Because of us. Rodrigues sounds as if he’s trying to convince himself of as well as give Garupe strength. Garupe HOLDS HIS ARMS OU Rodrigues and HUGS him quickly.

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: My prayers go with you.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: And my love with you.

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: I pray to be as strong as you. The priests WADE into the water toward their waiting fish boats. But Rodrigues TURNS QUICKLY...

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Stay alive! Promise me. Promise!

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: I promise. The priests hoist themselves into the waiting boats which quickly away from the beach. They are soon lost to each o under the cover of the dense starless night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An oar, CHURNING up the inky sea. A small boat breasts the waves, cutting through the pitch night. Rodrigues is its only passenger, a single BOATMAN sole crew. He will not look Rodrigues in the eye. Rodrigu hugs himself for warmth.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Is there any water? (no reply) Water? I'm very thirsty. The boatman does not reply. Perhaps he does not understan NOTE: NOW WHEN WE HEAR RODRIGUES V.0O., his voice is diff like a whisper, like a man telling secrets to himself. Th words are like a fervent prayer, part penitence, part reflection and part stream-of-consciousness struggle.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “Father in Heaven, praised be Thy name. I’m just a foreigner who brought disaster. That’s the way they think of me now. But if I’d been an ordinary Christian, and not a priest, wouldn’t I have also disgraced our Lord and run like Kichijiro? He trails his fingers in the sea and sucks the drops of s water from his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “I imagine Your Son, nailed to the cross, and my mouth tastes like vinegar.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shore, seen from the boat: the sun has not yet burnt the morning mist. The land looks shrouded, unwelcoming.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Is that Goto? The boatman TURNS the boat so Rodrigues can disembark. He HIS HAND OUT TO HELP Rodrigues, who, to the Boatman’s sur shakes it, then uses it to steady himself as he stands in boat rocking in the waves...  61 62 53 ...and STEPS over the side. The boatman QUICKLY ROWS away Rodrigues splashes toward shore like a thief in the night

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deserted. Huts in disrepair. Broken plates and cups and b furniture strewn in the dust. Doors broken. The only soun the wind. He smirks at the absurdity...then stops quickly, spinning the sound of the MEWING of a cat. The cat strides by itself. The cat goes past Rodrigues’ l Then more cats. And more. Until they are a silent phalanx parading silently, indifferently, past the staring priest

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rodrigues SCAVENGES for scraps of food. He DRINKS a bowl water greedily, SPLASHES what remains on his face, then g the doorway. There is nothing outside but desolation.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “I sleep standing, like a camel. I dream of mountains, and flight, and Our Saint Francis. What happened to all the glorious possibility he found here?” A cat walks down the empty street with a field mouse betw its jaws. Rodrigues leans against the door jamb. WE SEE H from behind: his body goes SLACK. The WIND BLOWS. Swarms flies fill the air.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “What have I done for Christ? What am I doing for Christ? What will I do for Christ?”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rodrigues CLIMBS a steep path up a craggy mountain. BLACK CIRCLE overhead, casting long, slow shadows in the aftern sun.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “One priest remaining in this country is like a single candle burning in the catacombs.” A shadow of a crow CROSSES RODRIGUES’ face, startling him

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “But everything I see only fills me with unease. And I feel danger. Everywhere.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rodrigues LOOKS DOWN from the top of the mountain on the deserted village of Goto and the implacable sea beyond. Rodrigues takes a cucumber from his bag and BITES into it ravenously.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “Saint Francis Xavier. And Cabral. Valignano himself. They crossed the black sea of Japan and were received with love. They didn’t have to run away.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rodrigues walks amongst tall reeds.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “Jesus's spirit was forged in the wilderness. Lord, grant me the strength to follow His example. For God so loved the world...”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU: Rodrigues' hands, with Mokichi’s cross between them, in morning prayer.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.0)
dialogues.text: “I feel so tempted to despair. I’m afraid. I pray, but I’m lost...or are You testing me? His forehead PRESSES so hard against the mountain stone i seems his skull might split. RODRIGUES (CONT’D) “How can I find Ferreira if there is no one to show me the way?” He gets up to begin his day’s journey, pulling his meager clothes close to his body for warmth...then SEES somethin ...the ashes of a fire. A faint glow of dying embers, on far side of a rocky path.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
