dialogues.text: “Is this Your sign that I am not alone?” Approaching warily, he reaches down to touch an ember. It still warm. He pulls his hand away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From above. A flock of crows hovers on a branch. They wat Rodrigues approaching in the distance. SUDDENLY the CAMER TAKES OFF like a bird and sails into an EXTREME CU of Rodrigues, flailing at a crow, knocking it away.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “Or is this Your sign?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up some stones and throws them at the birds, who away in a squawking panic. The sense of the desperation o situation--the isolation, the danger--overwhelms him.  68 69 56

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “Or no sign at all? I expected Your silence, but the weight of it is terrible. God, lend me the strength to be worthy of this trial and to remain faithful to Jesus.” A cloud obliterates the last traces of sun.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: “Despair is the greatest sin, but in the mystery of Your silence, it crowds my heart.” RAIN begins, splashing his face in large drops. He looks shelter. Leaves are splattered by giant rain drops. The t trees sway in the wind like seaweed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A poor HUT in the distance. Rodrigues HURRIES toward it a RAIN FALLS HARDER, soaking him through.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “But I will not give in. I pray for Your forgiveness. I will find the man who set the fire. Any man. Even if he brings danger. To help and guide me.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rodrigues stares into the hut. Water drips through the th roof.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “I thought, I hoped, that even if there was only one man here I could renew my mission.” The hut is empty. Rodrigues looks disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “But Our Lord urged me on.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Following day. Rodrigues gazes down on a village below hi

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: “To find a place to begin again.” The poor village below shines in the sunlight. It seems l marvelous place to him. RODRIGUES (CONT’D) (softly) “How lovely are thy tabernacles, O Lord of hosts!” Everything you have created is good.” Using a stick for a staff, he hurries toward the village.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “You brought me here to bring the water of life to these poor people.” In his eagerness, he SLIPS on the rocky earth, STUMBLES, his balance. The staff drops from his hand. He TUMBLES do slope, BLOODYING his face...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .».-as he HITS the bottom of the slope, CRYING OUT in pai rolls over, trying to pick himself up... ...and finds himself FACE TO FACE with KICHIJIRO, who is BRANDISHING the staff like a club. They STARE at each oth astonishment. Kichijiro HELPS Rodrigues to his feet and hands him his s

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: I thought I was being followed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kichijiro helps wipe the blood from Rodrigues' face. A sm fire SMOKES in the corner. Rain LEAKS from the thatched r

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: Why did you come here, Padre? This place is dangerous. Where are you going?  73 58

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Nowhere. He TAKES Kichijiro’s rag and finishes cleaning himself.

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: We must be careful. There’s a price of three hundred pieces of silver for you.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Three hundred...Judas got only thirty.

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: There are Kirishitans in other places. Not far. We can hide there. I will take care of you. Rodrigues says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. The rain has stopped. Kichijiro is crouched over t fire, chewing on grass and cooking fish.

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: I hope you are not angry with me, Padre. I was only following your instructions. Faithfully. (beat) I was ashamed to step on our Lord’s face and now I am an outcast again. Mokichi and my family stayed strong, like roots of a tree. But I'm weak. I'll never grow. No man knows his strength until he is tested. Kichijiro HOLDS OUT a small piece of fish which he has co over the fire. KICHIJIRO (cont'd) Take it. Please. Rodrigues is hungry, but wary too. Kichijiro sets the fis front of him with a tiny but uncharacteristic flourish.

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: You must be so hungry. Rodrigues takes the fish and DEVOURS it in quick bites.  74 59

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: I do not know how Mokichi could be so strong. I am so weak.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Are you? You can certainly look after yourself.

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: Not to be selfish, only to find my way to God. I’m like you. I have nowhere else to go. I was made weak, where is the place for a weak man in a world like this? Rodrigues looks at Kichijiro with pity.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Saint Paul said, “When I am weak, then I am strong.” Do you want to confess for Mokichi and Ichizo? Kichijiro NODS and KNEELS. A lizard scurries across the g and around his legs. Rodrigues pronounces a blessing.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: “In nomine Patris et Filii et Spiritus Sancti...” As the confession continues, we also hear...

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “Our Lord is crowned with thorns. Our Lord is crucified...” .+-and the words of the confession become Rodrigues’ whis prayer.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "What you will do, do quickly.” Your Son's words to Judas at the Last Supper. Was he angry when He said them? Or did they come from love?”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rodrigues lies on the ground near Kichijiro, who squats n smoking fire. The priest would appear to be sleeping, but eyes are wide open.  60

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “And if Jesus loved Judas, why didn't He stop him?” Kichijiro looks at Rodrigues, who closes his eyes tight.

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: Padre? Are you asleep? (no response) Padre? Rodrigues still does not answer. After a moment, his eyes flutter, as if he’s waking... -and looks for Kichijiro. But Kichijiro is gone.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: "What you will do, do quickly." He LIES DOWN again, resigned to whatever fate Kichijiro m have in store...but Kichijiro WALKS IN FROM THE SHADOWS, loaded with twigs which he dumps on the fire.

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: Did you say something, Padre?

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Prayers. Rodrigues TURNS AWAY from him and, relieved, closes his e

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: Don’t you trust me by now? No one trusts me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kichijiro’s staff PIERCES the body of a snake in the gras the side of the road. He holds the dying reptile up.

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: Take this. We eat them for medicine. Rodrigues shakes his head and walks on. Kichijiro pulls t wiggling snake from his staff and throws it into the gras

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A path through a deep wood. SUN SHINES down in shafts thr the dense trees. The heat makes WHITE STEAM RISE on the r Kichijiro WALKS several yards in front of Rodrigues.

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: We won't reach the village today if we can not walk faster. (turns) Are you all right, Padre? You seem tired.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Just...no, I'm all right. Just so thirsty. The fish was so salty.

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: I will find you some water. Keep walking. Kichijiro takes a water vessel from his pouch.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: No, that's all right, I...I thirst.

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: Our Lord said that.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Yes. I mean...I ate so much of that fish. You made me.

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: For strength. Kichijiro DASHES from the path and into the wood, holding small water vessel. Rodrigues is alone. He walks a few st stops, looks around. He is exhausted and uncertain. He SI HIS KNEES and prays aloud.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Lord, hear me. My foot is on the path, but I don't know where it leads. As Rodrigues prays, CAMERA MOVES BACK, FURTHER AND FURTHE

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Please, Lord, lead me. Give me Your hand... SUDDEN CUT TO: the water vessel, FALLING AND SMASHING on ground. Kichijiro stares at Rodrigues.  77 62

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: I am sorry, Padre. I thought something was wrong. (as Rodrigues gets up) But never mind. There is a stream just nearby. You can drink as much as you like. Rodrigues resignedly FOLLOWS Kichijiro off the path.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rodrigues' face, REFLECTED in the water as he kneels by t bank. As he stares at it, the gentle current shifts, crea RIPPLES that change the reflection_to the image of... ...desus: much the same image as in the Evora chapel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rodrigues LAUGHS and PLUNGES his face into the water, BRE the image. He DRINKS deeply from the river, then raises h head. He SEES his reflection again. He SCOOPS up a handfu water, rubs it on his face. When he lowers his arm, HE SE ...THE SAMURAI COMMANDER. Frightened, Rodrigues JUMPS to feet and backs into the stream. ...but SEES: a HALF-DOZEN SAMURAI and GUARDS. Rodrigues knows he is trapped. He tries to hide his panic The Samurai Commander SIGNALS his men. They quickly cross stream and seize Rodrigues firmly but not forcibly. Rodri bag falls from him and the contents spill out (his chalic paten, pyx with hosts, wine flask, missal, crucifix, and notebook.) Then the Samurai Commander inclines his head i direction of... ..-Kichijiro, who is watching from a large rock a few yar away. The Samurai Commander THROWS A HANDFUL OF TINY SILV PIECES at him. Kichijiro lets them lie where they fell as watches Rodrigues being LED OFF through the thick brush.

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: Padre, forgive me! I am weak. I told you I am weak. God knows I am weak but will He still love me? Isn't that what you promised? Does God still love me? The Samurai Commander stares at Kichijiro impassively.

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: I pray for God's forgiveness. Will He hear me?  78 63 Rodrigues TURNS to look at Kichijiro, who stares after hi getting smaller and smaller as Rodrigues is pulled away.

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: Even me? Will He forgive even me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SUN is merciless. HEAT WAVES rise from the earth. Rodrigues, PULLED by his captors, stumbles along the path swallowing dust. PEASANTS and VILLAGERS on the route star him. Rodrigues tries to smile at a boy who looks at him w eyed, but his cracked lips only make his mouth wrinkle.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “And the word was with God, and the word was God." The procession, with Rodrigues in the middle, leaves the for a field. FIVE PEASANTS, BOUND, STARE in amazement as. ..-Rodrigues approaches. Guards nonchalantly place the pr in the midst of the peasants who BOW as he settles on the ground. He notices a tiny twig HUT in the near distance. whole scene is unexpectedly peaceful.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So quiet. Like a day of peace and prayer, not a day of sacrifice. I won't be a martyr today. “The Lord is near to the brokenhearted and saves the crushed in spirit.” Thank you, Father. “Everything is Yours, do with it what You will. Give me only Your love and Your grace. That is enough for me.” A PEASANT WOMAN (MONICA) reaches into her blouse and retr a cucumber, which she offers to Rodrigues. The sound of f humming.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Blessed be God. Arigataya...what is your name?

dialogues.speaker: MONICA
dialogues.text: Monica.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Like the mother of Augustine.  64

dialogues.speaker: MONICA
dialogues.text: My baptism name. That man is Juan. She pronounces it “Ju-wan,” which is the way everyone pronounces it throughout. Rodrigues nods at the man, whos eyelid lies lifeless over his left eye. The taste of the cucumber is foul in his mouth, as bitter as the fear he t to suppress. But he’s ravenous. He keeps eating. MONICA (cont'd) He wanted his name to be like our priest who died at Unzen.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: (unguarded) There will be many more joining him. They look at him blankly. A sudden desperation escapes hi temper flares.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Why are you looking like that? Why are you so calm? Don’t you understand? We're all going to die like that. Soon. They look at him with growing astonishment and he immedia begins to feel remorse for his outburst. He forces down t last bite of cucumber.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Thank you...for the food.

dialogues.speaker: MONICA
dialogues.text: Arigataya. But Padre...our father...Padre Juan...said if we die we will go to paraiso.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Paradise, yes...

dialogues.speaker: MONICA
dialogues.text: Isn't it good to die? Paraiso is so much better than here. No one hungry, never sick. No taxes, no hard work.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: (conciliatory) Padre Juan was right. There’s no work in paraiso. No taxes, no hunger. Nothing can be stolen from you. And there’s no pain.... (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 65 RODRIGUES (cont'd) (beat) Were there other priests?

dialogues.speaker: MONICA
dialogues.text: Only Padre Juan.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Was there a Padre Ferreira? (as Monica struggles to pronounce the name) Ferreira? Did you ever hear of him? Monica shakes her head. Rodrigues LOOKS AWAY toward the O SAMURAI approaching with two peasants. He seems to be ste straight out of the broiling sun. He DEFTLY WIELDS A FAN ward off FLIES that buzz perpetually in the steaming air SQUATS on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: OLD SAMURAI
dialogues.text: You all, I wish you would stop causing me_so much trouble - please - in this heat, and the dust. They are especially bad this year. We shouldn’t be traveling so far at our age. And it’s all so unnecessary. Just make a little effort to understand our point of view. We don’t hate you. There’s no real reason for this trouble. You’ve brought it on yourself. And you can rid yourself of it too. They keep their eyes on the ground, not looking at him.

dialogues.speaker: OLD SAMURAI
dialogues.text: No_ need to feel lost. I’ll give you time to think it over. Then you can give me a reasonable answer. Go_on now. He gestures them away and they RISE. Rodrigues gets up wi them but the Old Samurai SNAPS OUT...

dialogues.speaker: OLD SAMURAI
dialogues.text: Not you! (beat) You stay. Rodrigues, startled, sits back down on the ground. The Ol Samurai stands, sips from a cup of water. OLD SAMURAI (cont'd) You understood what I was saying to them? Your Japanese is good enough?  66

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: I saw your eyes.

dialogues.speaker: OLD SAMURAI
dialogues.text: And what did you think you saw there? (Rodrigues does not answer) They’re fools, those peasants. Rodrigues GLANCES AT the prisoners being led away.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Lord spare them suffering and keep them safe in Your hand.

dialogues.speaker: OLD SAMURAI
dialogues.text: They can talk among themselves without end and decide nothing. Not one can think for himself. But you understand, don’t you?

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Just say what you mean.

dialogues.speaker: OLD SAMURAI
dialogues.text: That it all depends on you whether they are set free. Your Kirishitan God is sensible, at least in some things. Let him tell you to deny your faith.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: And if I refuse you’1ll kill me? “The blood of martyrs is the seed of the church.” Like the priests in Omura and Nagasaki. The Old Samurai looks at him sharply.

dialogues.speaker: OLD SAMURAI
dialogues.text: Been thinking about this, have you? Killing the peasants makes it worse. If they can die for their Deusu they think it only makes them stronger.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: If you have to do it, punish me alone.

dialogues.speaker: OLD SAMURAI
dialogues.text: (angry) You do not speak like a good priest. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 79 67 OLD SAMURAI (cont'd) If you are a real man, a truly good priest, you should feel pity for the Kirishitan. Isn’t that so, Padre? Isn't that so? He gets up. Rodrigues does not respond. OLD SAMURAI (cont'd) The price for your glory is their suffering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the hut that Rodrigues glimpsed in the distance i previous scene. Guards PUSH him inside. He loses his bala and falls to the dirt. The guards laugh and leave. He tries to pray. He recites the Pater Noster and the Ave Maria, but the words are dry in his mouth. A BURST OF LIGHT hits him. The INTERPRETER is silhouetted against the outside light. Rodrigues’ face remains in ful light that is sometimes so strong he has to BLINK.

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: Padre? (continues in heavy accent) Louvado seja Deus, nosso Pai.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: (replies, smiling slightly) Praise be to Him.

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: The Portuguese language was a gift of your Father Cabral. I’ve been asked to interpret on your behalf.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Behalf?

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: (continuing) There was concern that we might miss certain subtleties in your testimony...

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Testimony...  68

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: (still continuing on) ..-if you were confined to Japanese. We wanted to be fair. And we do have a better grasp of your language than you do of ours. Cabral could never manage much more than arigataya. All the time he lived here he taught but would not learn. He despised our language, our food, our customs.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: I’m not like Cabral.

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: Really? (pause) Would you like to go outside? We do not think you’1l run.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Are you sure? I’m not a saint and I’m afraid of death.

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: I admire your honesty, Padre. Courage can so often be blind. But that is the kind of courage that does violence to us and causes us endless trouble.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Is that all you think we brought you? Violence and endless trouble?

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: We have our own religion, Padre. Pity you did not notice it.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: We think a different way.

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: True. You say our Buddhas are all men.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: A Buddha dies too. Like all men. He is different from the Creator.

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: You are ignorant, Padre. Only a Christian would see Buddhas simply as men. Our Buddha is a being which man can become. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 69 INTERPRETER (cont'd) Something greater than himself, if he can overcome all his illusions. But you cling to your illusions and call them faith. (Rodrigues does not reply) Your Creator is all loving and all merciful, so you believe. Then why does he give people so much suffering on the way to heaven?

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: You don’t understand. If any man observes God’s commandments, he...

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: (interrupting) I do understand, Padre. It’s perfectly simple. Korobu. Do you know this word? You should know it. It means fall down. Surrender. Give up the faith. Apostatize, as you say. Do it or your dear peasants will enjoy one of those trials that come so often from your God. They will see the world from His vantage. From above. But they will be upside down, hanging over a pit. Things start to look very different from there. They did to Fathers Porro and Cassola. Have you heard of them? There was one called Pedro, too. And Ferreira of course.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Ferreira?

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: Did you know him?

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: I've heard of him.

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: No doubt. He’s well known all over Japan now. The priest with the Japanese name. And the Japanese wife.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: (stunned) I don’t believe you.

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: You can ask anyone. People in Nagasaki point him out and marvel.  80 81 82 83 70 Rodrigues SHAKES HIS HEAD, trying to deny what he’s heard Interpreter sees that his information has made an impact.

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: He’s held in great esteem now. Which, I believe, is why he came here in the first place. The Interpreter STEPS OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Interpreter looks casually at the guards.

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: Arrogant. Like all of them. But he’ll fall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rodrigues is praying fervently now, in contrast to his pr of only minutes before. He has been shaken by the news of Ferreira.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Lord, forgive me for my pride. Give me the strength Father Ferreira did not have. If he could not stand up to the test, how can I? I thought martyrdom would be my salvation. Dear God, do not let it be my shame. CcuT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rodrigues rests his head against the side of the boat whi moves forward under full sail. We think at first he is pr But his eyes are wide open, and his lips are still.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Lord, I feel the weight of their fate. Those who have died. Those who will die. Like the weight of Your silence.  84 71 Rodrigues raises his head as he hears a SOUND: the choppy rhythmic dip of a distant oar in the water. In the shadow Interpreter notices Rodrigues staring into the night.

dialogues.speaker: BOATMAN
dialogues.text: Is anyone there?

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Someone's following.

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: Someone night fishing. Leave him alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A JAPANESE WORKER drops his shovel and RUSHES TOWARD THE CAMERA, As he comes closer, he is joined by a dozen other gaping toward... ..-Rodrigues, on an aged horse. He attracts more attentio way. He is MUTTERING a psalm.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: “The Lord is my refuge and my deliverer. My God is my helper, and in Him will I put my trust.” A WOMAN APPROACHES, holding two CHILDREN by the sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: CHILD
dialogues.text: Look how big he is. A small band of STROLLING MINSTRELS (wearing hakama) LAUG provide musical accompaniment to Rodrigues’ halting progr

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: “Of the blood all price exceeding, shed by our Immortal King, destined, for the world’s redemption...” NOW WE SEE: Rodrigues is among a group of other prisoners guards. All prisoners but Rodrigues are bound and being P along. Black clothed BUDDHIST PRIESTS point at Rodrigues.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: “We adore you, O Christ, and we bless you ...”  85 86 72 Travelers with hats huge as umbrellas and straw coats GAP MAN in the crowd THROWS DIRT. RODRIGUES (cont'd) “,..because by your holy cross you have redeemed the world.” Rodrigues turns toward the man who threw the dirt at him, the crowd responds with further jeering. And in their mid Rodrigues SEES... ..-Kichijiro, staring at him in pity, fear and shame.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: (calling to him) Was it you last night? Kichijiro slinks back into the crowd. Beyond him, in the distance, WE SEE... ..-Nagasaki. It’s a city still under construction. SOUNDS BUILDING accompany the procession as it moves steadily to the city and a hill on which stands a...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PROCESSION ENTERS the prison gate. Rodrigues looks at new place of confinement, trying to mask his emotion.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. NEW PRISON RODRIGUES’ CELL DAY 86 Light STREAMS THROUGH a small window. SOUNDS of the city built up drift from outside: CRIES of working men; sounds trees being SAWED and nails being DRIVEN. CU on Rodrigues: he is MAKING A ROSARY from bits of paper string. His beard and hair have grown. The SOUND of the N being pounded makes him reflective.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Thank you, Lord, for the gentle days here, and I pray...I hope...I have found the strength for whatever awaits me at their end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In A QUICK SERIES OF TIME CUTS, WE SEE: Rodrigues, minist to the other prisoners, including Monica and her husband reciting passages from Scripture; hearing confession by pressing his ear to the hole through which food is passed other prisoners huddle in the cell corner.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Even the guards here have been touched by Your hand. My ministry to the other prisoners is a precious gift to me and, I hope, a help to them. WE INTERCUT the glimpses of Rodrigues and the prisoners w SHOTS of him fashioning the rosary from paper and string.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I feel so close to you now, Father. I see the life of Your Son so clearly, almost like my own. And His face. It takes all fear from me. It’s the face I remember from childhood, the face I saw at Evora. INT. NEW PRISON RODRIGUES’ CELL DAY 86B Rodrigues stares at the dirt floor of his cell AND IMAGIN face of Christ from the Evora chapel looking back at him.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Speaking to me. I’m sure of it. Promising “I will not abandon you.” Rodrigues stares at the image of Christ and REPEATS ALOUD

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: “I will not abandon you...will not abandon...” Suddenly an untidy package of clothes falls across the im Christ like a great blot. Rodrigues looks up startled. A stands at the door.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Put those on. Hurry up, or we won’t let you have any more paper and string for your toys. (as Rodrigues hesitates) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 87 74 GUARD (cont'd) Jittoku. You should be honored. It’s what our priests wear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FIVE SAMURAI are seated formally in the yard, the Old Sam in the middle, the Interpreter next to him. They all hold which they SWISH in the stifling air. Rodrigues, wearing the clothes of the Buddhist priest, SQ at the hot sun. Then GLANCING to his left, he SEES... ---Monica, Juan and the other prisoners watching through small cell window as he seats himself on the ground. He i aware of his responsibility to be strong for them.

dialogues.speaker: SAMURAI 1
dialogues.text: Father Rodrigues? From Portugal, yes? I am sorry, Padre, for my speaking. My language is not so good. But His Lordship the Governor of Chikugo is anxious about your comfort...comfort?

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: Perhaps “discomfort.”

dialogues.speaker: SAMURAI 1
dialogues.text: Discomfort, yes. About why you are here. And... He looks to the Interpreter, who nods. SAMURAI 1 (cont'd) ...if you are not at ease, please say so. (Rodrigues BOWS his head) You also have...have...moved on the water... Unsatisfied with the way he’s expressing himself, he look the Interpreter again, then BEGINS SPEAKING RAPIDLY IN JAPANESE. The Interpreter translates swiftly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Japanese) Your trip was long. There were many dangers. The power of your determination touches us_ greatly. We know you have also suffered greatly. We do hot wish to add to your suffering. 75

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: (translating as Samurai 1 speaks) “Your trip was long. There were many dangers. The power of your determination touches us greatly. We know you have also suffered greatly. We do not wish to add to your suffering.” These words pierce Rodrigues’ heart. They are gently spok but he senses the threat that lurks beneath them.

dialogues.speaker: SAMURAI 1
dialogues.text: And the thought that we might do_so is painful for us too.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: SAMURAI 1
dialogues.text: Father, the doctrine you bring with you may be true in Spain and Portugal. But we have studied it carefully thought about it over much time...and find it’s of no use and no value in Japan. We have concluded that it is a danger. INTERPRETER (cont'd) “And the thought that we might do so is painful for us too.”

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: “Father, the doctrine you bring with you may be true in Spain and Portugal. But we have studied it carefully...thought about it over much time...and find it is of no use and no value in Japan. We have concluded that it is a danger.” The Old Samurai watches Rodrigues formulate his reply wit great interest. Samurai 1 occasionally whispers a transla to the Old Samurai.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: But we believe we brought you the truth, and the truth is universal. It’s common to all countries at all times, that’s why we truth. If a doctrine in Japan as it is in couldn’t call it the call it the weren’t as true Portugal, we truth. The Old Samurai nods his head in agreement. Rodrigues fee encouraged. He has one ally in this severe tribunal.  76

dialogues.speaker: SAMURAI 1 INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: I_see you do not work with “I see you do not work with your hands, Father. But your hands, Father. But everyone knows _a tree which everyone knows a tree which flourishes in one kind of flourishes in one kind of earth may decay and die in earth may decay and die in another. It is the same with another. It is the same with the tree of Christianity. The the tree of Christianity. T leaves decay here. The buds leaves decay here. The buds die. die.”

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: (heated) It is not the soil that has killed the buds. There were three hundred thousand Christians in Japan before the soil was...

dialogues.speaker: SAMURAI 1
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Poisoned. Samurai 1 has to restrain his anger over this response. O the OLD SAMURAI seems to understand what Rodrigues means, even sympathize with it. The priest is encouraged by the Samurai’s response. He GLANCES BRIEFLY over at the prison watching from their cell window, and continues boldly... RODRIGUES (cont'd) You have no reply? Why should you? You're never going to change my mind and I’m not going to change yours. If you really want to test my faith, give me a real challenge. Take me to the Inquisitor. Bring me to Inoue Sama. There is a lingering moment of BAFFLED SILENCE. Then... ...LAUGHTER. Even a BENIGN SMILE from the Old Samurai.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I didn’t think I was here for your amusement. (as laughter continues) What are you laughing at? The laughter dies after a few moments.

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: Because, Padre...  88 77 The Old Samurai INTERRUPTS with a FLICK of his fan.

dialogues.speaker: OLD SAMURAI
dialogues.text: Because I am the Governor of Chikugo, Padre. I am the Inquisitor. I am Inoue. Rodrigues is STUNNED. The Old Samurai RISES and walks out the yard. The other samurai follow. From behind him, Rodrigues hears the prisoners singing a As the Guards take him back to his cell, he sees all thei faces there, singing, and he feels he has done well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOLES IN THE GROUND, being dug by prisoners as RAIN POURS and Rodrigues WATCHES from his cell window. A Guard WALKS and the priest calls to him.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: How long will they have to work in this rain?

dialogues.speaker: PRISON GUARD
dialogues.text: (heavy accent) Until finished.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: What are the holes for?

dialogues.speaker: PRISON GUARD
dialogues.text: (casually) Privies. The Guard walks on...and Rodrigues SEES, near the prison entrance, a MAN IN A CAPE standing, unmoving, in the rain Guard CHASES him away with threatening gestures. The man retreats. The Guard walks on... .+.and the Man STEALS BACK, and stands there. Looking at prisoners. Looking toward Rodrigues. TIME CUT: the Man in the Cape stands close to the window now...close enough for Rodrigues to recognize him.

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: (calling out) Padre! Padre! Please listen to me!  89 78 His pleas DRAW GUARDS, who RUSH at him with sticks. He lo afraid, takes a step back, but then stands his ground. KICHIJIRO (cont'd) I was forced to step on our Lord’s face! God made me weak then asks me to be strong. That’s not fair. The Guards are GRAPPLING with him now, but he keeps calli to Rodrigues, who COVERS HIS EARS.

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: They threatened me! The officials...but I never took their money! I didn’t betray you for money!

dialogues.speaker: PRISON GUARD
dialogues.text: Get out of here now or we will hurt you worse.

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: Go_ahead! I am a Kirishitan! Put me in prison! I am a Kirishitan! The Guards are happy to oblige. They drag Kichijiro throu mud and rain past Rodrigues’ window. Kichijiro looks at h pleadingly. Rodrigues reaches out his hand in blessing... STOPS.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Did Jesus pray for Judas? He watches from the shadows as Kichijiro is DRAGGED AWAY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rodrigues STEPS INTO the cell, SEES: the Christian prison seated together in a group, some speaking among themselve others praying. Seeing the priest, Monica glances toward corner of the cell and WE PAN to REVEAL: Kichijiro, crouc in the shadow, separated from the others. Shivering.

dialogues.speaker: MONICA
dialogues.text: Be careful of him, Padre. Maybe Inoue Sama pays him to make us trample.

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: No! He did not! Padre...Padre, let me confess. Please, Padre.  79 The other prisoners watch as Rodrigues--reluctantly; wari goes to Kichijiro and kneels beside him. Kichijiro is fil and smells foul, and instinctively Rodrigues moves back.

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: I know I smell. I smell of sin. I know. I want to confess again, so the Lord can wash me clean.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Why did you come here? Is it for absolution? Do you understand what absolution is?

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: (quietly, almost casually) Do you understand what I’ve been saying? Yes, Padre, I denied. I’m an apostate. Years ago. I could have died a good Kirishitan. There was no persecution. Why was I born now? This is so unfair...I’m sorry... The Prisoners watch and listen with great interest.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: But do you still believe? Kichijiro looks down. He can’t answer. As Rodrigues makes blessing and Kichijiro begins his confession:

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: In némine Patris et Filii et Spiritus Sancti.

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: I am sorry - for being so weak. I am sorry this has happened. I am sorry for what I did to you. Please, help me take away the sin. I will try again to be strong.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: (giving absolution) Déminus noster Jesus Christus te absélvat; et ego auctoritate ipsius te absdélvo ab omni vinculo excommunicatiénis et interdicti in quantum possum et tu indiges. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: T9A
dialogues.text: RODRIGUES (cont'd) [making the sign of the cross]: Deinde, ego te absdélvo a peccatis tuis in némine Patris, et Filii, et Spiritus Sancti. Amen. As Rodrigues utters the words of absolution, WE HEAR...

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Father, how could Jesus love a wretch like this? There is evil all around in this place. I sense its strength. Even its beauty. But there is none of that in this man. He is not worthy to be called evil. Rodrigues FINISHES the absolution, then follows with the customary conclusion...

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: (whispering) Go in peace.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. NEW PRISON RODRIGUES’ CELL DAY 90 He stares at the floor, miserable about his failure of sp Jesus's face--the face from the Evora chapel--is before h  91 80 CUT TO: The eyes of Jesus, tight shot. They seem to look into Rodrigues’ very soul.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: As I feel...I fear...Jesus forgive me...I may not be worthy of You. Rodrigues hangs his head in shame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BURNING SUNLIGHT at midday. A row of five stools, and FIV OFFICIALS settle themselves on them. They stare indiffere at FOUR CHRISTIAN PRISONERS on the ground in front of the Rodrigues WATCHES from his cell window. The whole scene i played out from his POV, through the bars on the window. Sounds of CICADAS and the SWISH of a fan or RUSTLE of a f robe worn by an official punctuate the weary routine of t day. OFFICIAL # 1 almost sounds bored when he speaks up..

dialogues.speaker: OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: This is just _a formality, really. Just one step, that’s all. We’re not asking you_to do it sincerely. It’s only for appearances. Just putting your foot on the thing won’t betray your faith, whatever it is. Truthfully, I’m not interested. The sooner you get it over with the sooner we can all get out of the sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rodrigues can tell the Official is trying to disarm the prisoners, and he can’t be sure how they will react. OFFICIAL # 1 (cont'd) Put your foot on it and nobody will care what you believe. Just rest it...brush it...lightly, if you like...however you like, it’s not important...and you’ll be free. Immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guards come forward carrying the fumie. The Christians st the face of Christ on the fumie. Rodrigues SEES IT TOO, a his cell mutters a prayer.  81

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Lord, give them strength. Lord give me strength. The Official begins the formal ceremony by calling out fo by his Japanese name...

dialogues.speaker: OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: Chokichi... The Guards urge Monica’s one-eyed husband forward when he not respond. He stands with his head bowed.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: Go_ahead. Stamp on it. (Juan does not move) It’s only a picture. Crush it. Do it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juan can not, will not, obey. One of the Guards SWATS HIM impassively with a club, pulls his head back by the hair. Looking straight at Official # 1, Juan SHAKES HIS HEAD ag In a SERIES OF QUICK CUTS, Juan’s FACE is replaced by the OF MONICA...and then by the face of each of the other pri in the yard...EACH SHAKING THEIR HEADS in refusal. Official # 1 SIGHS, almost inaudibly, then RISES. The oth FOLLOW HIM into a hut at the far side of the yard. The te has dissipated. The Prisoners relax a little. Suddenly the VOICE of Official # 1 CALLS across the yard.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: Take them all back. But that one... (points to Juan) ..-he stays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Guards take three of the four prisoners to the hut. O Juan remains behind, continuing a conversation with the G

dialogues.speaker: GUARD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It_ seems a pity to throw it away so lightly.

dialogues.speaker: JUAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Well, it’s not lightly. But it does seem a pity. It sounds as if they’re talking about nothing more seriou a corn husk. Relieved, Rodrigues draws away from the wind rests his head against the cell wall.  82

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Thank you, Lord, for hearing my prayer. FLIES BUZZ around his face. He SHOOS them away with his h then HEARS the SOUND of someone RUNNING ACROSS the prison Then a kind of STEELY WHOOSHING SOUND... .»+-and then ANOTHER SOUND. A dull CLAP OF IMPACT. Curiou Rodrigues RETURNS to the window in time to see Juan’s sev head coming ROLLING past him in the dust. Rodrigues RECOILS. Official #1 and the Guard watch as Jua headless body drops to the ground. There are SCREAMS from hut as the Guard DRAGS Juan’s headless body to the RECENT HOLES in the yard and DUMPS it in. Rodrigues SHUDDERS at sight. Official # 1 stands in the doorway of the hut, speaking l now, for all to hear.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: You’ve seen an example of what can happen. Now here is a perfect example of how to avoid that fate. Bring him out here. Guards HAUL Kichijiro to the fumie.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: Go_ ahead. Just put your foot there. See how easy it is for him? I admit he’s had practice. But look how simple the movement is. Kichijiro, dressed only in a loincloth, puts his foot on face of Christ. OFFICIAL # 1 (cont'd) It’s not even as hard as bowing. Is it? Is it? Kichijiro NODS his head.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: Or running. Now go! Get out of here! You_see... He addresses the Prisoners now as Kichijiro DASHES for th prison gate...through the long RIBBON OF BLOOD on the gro from Juan's body.  92 83

dialogues.speaker: OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: He lived up to his obligation. We stand by ours. Kichijiro vanishes into the busy street outside. The Officials leave the hut. Guards take the prisoners ba their cell. The ordinary quiet of the yard is restored. Rodrigues stares into the bright stillness as if searchin something.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: “Eternal Lord of all things, I make my offering with Your favor and help. For Your greater service and praise, I wish and desire to imitate you in bearing all injuries and offenses...” The words turn to dust in his mouth. His LIPS move but no comes out.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Martyrdom. Holy martyrdom. Is that what this is?... ON THESE LAST WORDS, CUT TO: the trail of Juan’s blood in dust of the prison yard. Then back to..

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ..-what I’ve been preparing for? Praying for? But when I pray now I feel I’m blaspheming. And You answer with all I deserve. With silence. His VOICE fades out, until only the SOUND of the cicadas heard. And all that’s left in the yard are the shifting s of the passing Guards.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. INQUISITOR’S OFFICE DUSK 92 A BOWL OF HOT WATER is set in front of Inoue, who NODS in comradely fashion to Rodrigues, seated across from him. The Interpreter hands the priest ANOTHER BOWL OF WATER, w is HOT to the touch. Rodrigues places it on the ground. H distracted, uneasy. Unsettled by the violence he’s witnes  84

dialogues.speaker: INOUE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry I’ve neglected you for some days now, Padre, but I had business in Hirado. I hope you’1l get to go there yourself sometime.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: It must be very beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: INOUE
dialogues.text: Well, maybe more interesting than beautiful. There is an interesting story about the daimyo who ruled there. You could say life had overwhelmed him with generosity. He had four concubines. Four. They were all beautiful, but they...I’m sorry, maybe this is not a story for a celibate priest.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Please go on.

dialogues.speaker: INOUE
dialogues.text: In any case, they were beautiful, but they were all jealous, and they fought and fought without end. So the daimyo of Hirado drove them away from his castle and peace came into his life again. (beat) Do you think this story has a lesson?

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Yes. That this was a wise man as well as a great one.

dialogues.speaker: INOUE
dialogues.text: I'm glad you see it that way because it means you see as I do. The daimyo is like Japan. And these women are Spain, Portugal, Holland, England, each whispering bad, bad lies about the other into his ear. Each trying to gain the advantage against the other and destroy the house in the process. If you think this man is wise, then you must understand why we must outlaw the Kirishitan.  85

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Our church teaches monogamy. What if Japan were to choose one lawful wife from the four?

dialogues.speaker: INOUE
dialogues.text: You mean Portugal.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: I mean the holy church.

dialogues.speaker: INOUE
dialogues.text: (laughs lightly) Don't you think it would be better for the man to forget about foreign women and choose one of his own?

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Nationality is not so important in a marriage. What matters is love and fidelity.

dialogues.speaker: INOUE
dialogues.text: Love? Padre, there are men who are plagued by the persistent love of an ugly woman.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: That’s what you think missionary work is?

dialogues.speaker: INOUE
dialogues.text: Well, from my point of view...our point of view...yes. What is the word for_a woman who cannot bear children?

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: Barren.

dialogues.speaker: INOUE
dialogues.text: A barren woman cannot be a true wife.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: If the Gospel has lost its way here, it’s not the fault of the church. It’s the fault of those who tear the faithful from their faith like a husband from a wife.

dialogues.speaker: INOUE
dialogues.text: (Quietly) You mean me.  93 94 86 Rodrigues lets the question hang. Inoue doesn’t seem angr

dialogues.speaker: INOUE
dialogues.text: Padre, you missionaries do not seem to know Japan.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: And you, honorable Inquisitor, do not seem to know Christianity. Silence. They have checkmated one another. For the moment

dialogues.speaker: INOUE
dialogues.text: Padre, there are those...there are many...who think of your religion as a curse. I do not. I see it in another way. But still dangerous. (he rises) I'd like you to think about the persistent love of an ugly woman. And about how a barren woman should never be a wife. Inoue leaves, the Interpreter BOWING as he passes. There is the sound of MOSQUITOS SWARMING just outside the Somewhere nearby a HORSE NEIGHS. The Interpreter looks at Rodrigues with a mixture of disbelief--that someone shoul spoken to Inoue in such a way--and pity--at the prospect results of such talk. Rodrigues RETURNS HIS LOOK without comment. But, finally, THE BOWL OF HOT WATER in his hands and sips from it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A procession of CHILDREN wends spiritedly down a narrow s SINGING A SONG and CARRYING LANTERNS to various homes alo route. There is an air of celebration in the town.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. NEW PRISON RODRIGUES’ CELL NIGHT 94 A Guard enters the cell carrying two fresh thin straw mat Interpreter is with him. Rodrigues hands the Guard a bowl uneaten fish and rice.  95 87

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Give it to the others. I don’t need to be fattened for the slaughter.

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: Why do you say that? Inoue Sama sent the extra food especially for you. It’s for strength. You need strength.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Not your kind. (nods at new mats) You can take those too. The Guard disregards him and GATHERS UP the old straw mat replacing them with the new ones. The SOUND of CHILDREN’S VOICES singing the Urabon song drifts in from the outside EXT. /INT.

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: You understand the singing, Padre?

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Yes a little.

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: It is a song for the festival, Urabon. It is a night when everyone hangs lanterns and lights candles for our ancestors.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: All Souls’ Day.

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: A feast day in the West.

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: Oh. Well, I hope you’1l continue to be comfortable.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: NEW PRISON YARD & RODRIGUES’ CELL DAY 95 The woman Monica is DRAGGED BY GUARDS past Rodrigues’ win

dialogues.speaker: MONICA
dialogues.text: Padre...Padre, can you help...  96 88 At the window, Rodrigues REACHES his fingers through the opening and TOUCHES the fingers of the terrified Monica a is dragged toward other prisoners in the yard. The cell door opens and the Guard deposits a fresh set of clothing on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: You make a journey today. TIME CUT: Rodrigues carefully hides the cross Mokichi gav in his underclothes pants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RODRIGUES, bound, is helped from his horse by two Guards. Standing stiffly, HE SEES: a GROVE OF PINES near the wate There are FIVE SAMURAI squatting by baskets and eating. A CURTAIN has been set up, strung between two of the talles trees. Several stools are placed in front of it.

dialogues.speaker: SAMURAI
dialogues.text: Sit down. Go ahead. Better for you than a saddle, I think. Rodrigues sits. In the distance, he can just make out the OUTLINE OF PEOPLE coming haltingly toward the pine grove.

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: Padre, how are you feeling today? I am sure the air must feel good, even though you are in our newest prison. It is new. It is not so bad. The old prison was very tough on the padres. Rain. Wind. Very bad.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: When will Inoue Sama be here?

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: Oh he’s not coming today. Do you miss him?

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: He treats me kindly. Three meals a day. Extra bedding. All so my body will betray my heart. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 89 RODRIGUES (cont'd) That is your plan, isn’t it? That’s what you're waiting for?

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: Not at all. But we are waiting for someone today, that’s true. Inoue Sama wants you to meet him. He’ll be here any moment. He’s Portuguese, like yourself. You should have a lot to talk about.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Ferreira... The Interpreter smiles. The distant group of figures has much closer. Rodrigues can just make them out: TWO SAMURA THREE OTHERS. They are the three Christian prisoners. Mon in the lead. And, STRAGGLING BEHIND THEM ALL... ..-IS GARUPE. Haggard, wearing peasant clothing. Rodrigue struggles to contain himself.

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: Is it who you expected?

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: I want to talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: No hurry. It is early. Plenty of time. (fans himself) So tell me, Padre, this mercy Christians always talk about...what is it? The procession of prisoners and their guards HALTS. GUARD UNLOAD piles of straw mats from the pack animals.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: (agitated) Tell me where Garupe was captured.

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: Oh I cannot. I must not speak about the business of the Inquisitor’s office. But I can tell you... (leans closer) He knows you’re alive. Because we told him you apostatized. The Interpreter observes Rodrigues’ shock with satisfacti  90

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: Now...do you know what they use those mats for? Guards WRAP the straw mats around the bodies of the three prisoners..but NOT GARUPE. One of the officials is talkin seriously to him.

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: What could he be saying? Maybe this...” If you are a priest with true Christian charity, you must pity them. You will not let them die because you want your heaven.” Rodrigues is torn between desperation and fury as the Interpreter continues... INTERPRETER (cont'd) The Inquisitor promises that if Father Garupe apostatizes the three will be free. They did deny the faith in his office the other day anyway. They found it was not so difficult to take a small step onto the fumie.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: If they did it, then why are you still doing this? They did what you wanted and...

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Oh we do not want them. Three? Remember, there are still hundreds of Christian peasants on the islands off the coast. We want the Padre to deny and be an example to them, that is all. Then all this will be over.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: _. (praying) . Vitam praesta puram, iter para tutum...

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: Well, I hope Father Garupe’s answer won't be in Latin. I wonder what he will say. Oh look... On the beach, the prisoners have been tied securely in th straw mats and are being PRODDED WITH LANCES to board a b that waits in the shallow water.  91

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: Since you say mercy is the most important thing in Christianity, I hope Father Garupe agrees. Garupe RUNS to the water's edge and SHOUTS something. An official in the boat shouts back to him.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (praying; agonized) Oh God, please. Please. Let him deny...deny...for their sake... On the beach, Garupe TURNS AND SHOUTS toward the pine gro

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: Stop this! Help them! Rodrigues tenses at the sound of his voice.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dear Lord, don’t leave this to us. This responsibility You must bear. One of the guards on the boat STICKS a prisoner with his sending him into the water. The sea SOAKS the straw quick The man is PULLED DOWN under the waves, drowned.

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: “Lord, have mercy! Christ, have mercy!” And Garupe PLUNGES into the surf toward the boat. Guards PUSH another prisoner off the boat. The prisoner S like a stone. Garupe SWIMS like a man possessed of holy f The guards PROD Monica over the side. She hits the water Garupe GRABS HER. He starts to splutter a prayer, but the weight of the straw DRAGS them both down. He will not let

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: Help me, God! Forgive me - ! The boat turns, deliberately BEARING DOWN as Garupe and M STRUGGLE to the surface...and are SMASHED by the bow of t boat. Their bodies SINK. On shore, Rodrigues keeps staring at the water. He has ri his feet. Tears stream down his cheeks. The Interpreter STANDS suddenly, disgusted and angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a terrible business. Terrible! No matter how many times you see it. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: 91A
dialogues.text: 97 98 99 92 INTERPRETER (cont'd) Think about the suffering you have inflicted on these people just because of your selfish dream of a Christian Japan. Your Deus punishes Japan. Through you. Innocent blood is flowing again. At least Garupe was clean. But you. Your spirit is weak. You have no will. You do not deserve to be called a priest. Rodrigues stares at the relentless sea.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. NEW PRISON RODRIGUES’ CELL DAY 97 The Interpreter, looking through the window of the cell d SEES: Rodrigues, in the corner of the cell, half in shado

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: How is he today?

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Same as yesterday. Same as five days ago. No change.

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: Let _me know. CU: on the back of Rodrigues' head as he stares at the wa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first day of August - Hassaku. From his cell, Rodrigu see that the prison guards have opened the gate to watch procession of VILLAGE OFFICIALS, some wearing white katab walk in formation down the street on their way to present themselves before the daikan. One of the officials carrie ceremonial rice offering. INT. NEW PRISON RODRIGUES’ CELL NIGHT 99 Rodrigues’ cell, isolated in darkness--it occupies only a portion of the wide frame, matted. It looks like a small compartment in infinity. Rodrigues, sitting on the floor cell, looks tiny.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 100 101 102 103 104 93 INT. NEW PRISON RODRIGUES’ CELL NIGHT 100 Rodrigues, face in profile, as SOUNDS OF CELEBRATION drif from outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: August 15th, the night of Imomeigetu, a time when people ceremonially offer their harvest to the moon. The prison have decorated their hut with pampas grass and are noisil enjoying some alcohol. A guard carries a table of offerin (rice cakes and vegetables) for the moon from the guard h places it on the ground. He and the other guards look up the moon. The celebration continues.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. NEW PRISON RODRIGUES’ CELL NIGHT 102 The BACK of Rodrigues’ head as he MUTTERS...

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: His sweat became like drops of blood, Eloi, Eloi, lama sabacthani...why have you forsaken me. Your Son’s prayer on the cross.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE FACE OF CHRIST in the Evora chapel.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: A cry of fear and despair. You were silent. Even to Him.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. NEW PRISON RODRIGUES’ CELL NIGHT 104 Rodrigues, FULL FACE NOW.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Why? Why have you forsaken us? (whispering aloud) Stupid. Ludicrous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FLASHBACK: JUAN’S BODY BEING DRAGGED by one leg through t prison courtyard, leaving a trail of blood in the dust. INT. NEW PRISON RODRIGUES’ CELL - NIGHT 105A

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: (whispering) Ludicrous...you’re so ludicrous

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FLASHBACK: GARUPE, DROWNING, calling out to heaven.

dialogues.speaker: GARUPE
dialogues.text: Lord, have mercy! INT. NEW PRISON RODRIGUES’ CELL NIGHT 106A

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: He’s not going to answer. He’s not. Rodrigues BREAKS DOWN and laughs. INT./EXT. NEW PRISON RODRIGUES’ CELL NIGHT 107 At the door of his cell, watching, is the Interpreter.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Do_you want me to let you in?

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: In time. In the cell, Rodrigues’ laughter dies as it echoes in his He can’t understand what’s happening to him, to the one t on which he relied all his life...his faith.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. NEW PRISON RODRIGUES’ CELL DAY 108 WEEKS LATER: Rodrigues’ hair and beard are longer. The do BURSTS open, and the Interpreter peers in at him.  109 95

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: Padre, we’re going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rodrigues is being conveyed in a curtained palanquin. The Interpreter rides along outside.

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Today you'll meet someone different. The Interpreter PARTS THE CURTAINS.

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: Not the officials. Not Inoue Sama, who continues to be concerned for your well being. Someone else. Someone Inoue Sama thought might help you. Someone I think you will want to meet. The Interpreter CLOSES the curtains again. Rodrigues HEAR children playing nearby; bells being rung by the bonzes; SOUNDS of sawing and hammering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The palanquin, with a small escort of guards, moves throu growing city toward a new temple in the near distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the PALANQUIN ENTERS THE FRAME. It stops and the Interpreter’s HAND comes in and OPENS the curtains.

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: Come along, Padre. Rodrigues is helped from the palanquin. A Buddhist priest the Temple of the True Pure Land sect walks past and give a hostile look.  96

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: The bonzes do not like you priests. Nevermind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Interpreter and Rodrigues are seated comfortably. Rod is wary.

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: What is it Padre? The incense? The smell of meat? Perhaps there will be some for you to share. Rodrigues HEARS the SOUND OF DISTANT FOOTSTEPS. The Inter watches him closely.

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: Have you had any meat since you came to Japan? I don’t much like the smell myself... He watches the priest, amused. He knows what’s coming...o more precisely, who.

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: Have you guessed yet? Rodrigues doesn’t seem to hear him.

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: Have you guessed who’s coming? (Rodrigues’ face stiffens) This is Inoue Sama’s command. And the other’s wish...

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: The other? Rodrigues looks down the long corridor off the garden, SE old Buddhist priest. And behind him, a tall man in a blac kimono. His eyes are down... .-+-until he sits in the dimming afternoon sunlight. Then looks up. His expression is enigmatic. But his eyes are d and dark, like coals that once glowed bright but now are out.  97

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: (after a silence) Father...I'd given up...Father Ferreira... The Old Priest is on Ferreira’s right, the Interpreter be them. He whispers a translation of the two priests’ conversation to the Old Priest.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Father, so long since we have met... Please... say...something.

dialogues.speaker: FERREIRA
dialogues.text: What can I say to you on such an occasion?

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: If you have pity for me... please... say something. Ferreira does not reply.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Have you been living here for long?

dialogues.speaker: FERREIRA
dialogues.text: About a year I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: What is this place?

dialogues.speaker: FERREIRA
dialogues.text: A temple called Saishoji. Where I study. Rodrigues looks steadily at the older priest.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: I also am in a prison somewhere in Nagasaki. Where precisely it is I do not know myself.

dialogues.speaker: FERREIRA
dialogues.text: I know it.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: (quietly) You were my teacher. You were my confessor...  98

dialogues.speaker: FERREIRA
dialogues.text: I am much the same.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. INQUISITOR’S OLD PRISON YARD NIGHT 113 1633. A pale face in a vast darkness: Ferreira. Covered i sweat. His blazing blue eyes showing signs of pain and te struggle. What little is visible of his body seems rigid, and not j with fear. It seems to be in conflict with gravity itself war outside itself as well as within. And this is why. The ANGLE of the scene seems to PIVOT. Ferreira’s world s literally to turn UPSIDE DOWN. But the world is not out o balance. It is Ferreira himself. He is bound and SUSPENDED UPSIDE DOWN over a pit just vis in GLIMMERS of light at the edges of this foul place. A TEAR RUNS from his eye...down his CHEEK...where it JOIN thin TRICKLE OF BLOOD from the side of his head. A O.S. VOICE belonging to the INQUISITOR INOUE speaks sof WE DO NOT SEE HIS FACE.

dialogues.speaker: INOUE
dialogues.text: I am only asking you to take the path of mercy. Abandon yourself. Do a single, simple thing. Ferreira’s head moves slightly. Perhaps a nod of assent.

dialogues.speaker: INOUE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Once you understand. Completely. Beyond a doubt. You will agree. It is the only way. Tell me then, Padre. Tell me you agree. Yes. Ferreira NODS his head: yes.

dialogues.speaker: INOUE
dialogues.text: Good. You take this unnecessary burden from us both.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 114 99 EXT. INQUISITOR’S OLD PRISON YARD NIGHT 114 A HAND comes into frame, placing a fumie with a sacred im metal on the dusty ground. Ferreira, TREMBLING, stands over it.

dialogues.speaker: INOUE
dialogues.text: Now show me. With only a step. Ferreira hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: INOUE
dialogues.text: Not because your body is weak. Show me how strong you are. Show me your new heart. With just one step. Step on your Jesus. Ferreira RAISES his right foot, then brings it down on th fumie. Ferreira collapses on the ground on top of the fum shuddering as if his soul has abandoned him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to the present. Ferreira looks at the younger priest solicitously.

dialogues.speaker: FERREIRA
dialogues.text: Do I really seem so different?

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: The honorable Sawano spends his day writing. About astronomy.

dialogues.speaker: FERREIRA
dialogues.text: At Inoue Sama’s order. There is great knowledge here, but in medicine and astronomy much remains to be taught. I'm happy to help. I’d like to show you the lenses and telescope the physician Albrecht just brought us. They're very beautiful. Rodrigues stares at him incredulously. FERREIRA (cont'd) It’s fulfilling to finally be of use in this country.  100 Rodrigues notices that Ferreira is SPEAKING so that the Interpreter and the Old Priest CAN HEAR.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Then you are happy, Father?

dialogues.speaker: FERREIRA
dialogues.text: I said so. The Old Priest looks IRRITABLE AND IMPATIENT at the cours this conversation. The Interpreter intervenes.

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Mention the other book you’re writing. Rodrigues notices that Ferreira HESITATES. INTERPRETER (cont'd) It is called Kengiroku. It shows the errors of Christianity and refutes the teachings of Deus. Do you understand the title? Rodrigues searches Ferreira’s face for some sense of shame...even embarrassment. Ferreira lowers his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: Tell him.

dialogues.speaker: FERREIRA
dialogues.text: (quietly) It means Deceit Disclosed. Or Unmasked, if you prefer a more florid reading. His Lordship the Inquisitor has read the manuscript. He praises it. He says it is well done. Rodrigues is stunned. He SHAKES HIS HEAD in denial.

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: It’s the truth.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: You use the truth like poison.

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: What a funny thing for a priest to say. Rodrigues LOOKS AGAIN at Ferreira, who CAN’T MEET HIS EYE  101

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: It’s cruel, worse than any torture. To twist a man’s soul this way. Ferreira TURNS HIS FACE AWAY from Rodrigues...but Rodrigu thinks he glimpsed the trace of a tear in Ferreira’s eye. Perhaps this man he revered above all others has not chan thoroughly after all. The Old Priest continues to look on everyone like a stone Buddha.

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: I think you must be speaking of yourself, Padre. Not of Sawano Chuan.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: Him. He is Ferreira only to you. He is Sawano Chuan now. A man who has found peace. Let him guide you along his path. The path of mercy. That means only that you abandon self. No one should interfere with another man’s spirit. To help others is the way of the Buddha and your way too. The two religions are the same in this. It’s not necessary to win anyone over to one side or another when there is so much to share. (to Ferreira) Go on.

dialogues.speaker: FERREIRA
dialogues.text: I’ve been told to get you to abandon the faith. He turns his head so Rodrigues can SEE a scar behind his

dialogues.speaker: FERREIRA
dialogues.text: This is from the pit. You are tied so you can’t move then hung upside down and the incision is made. You feel the blood running down your cheek drop by drop. So it doesn’t run to your head and you won’t die too soon.

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: It was Inoue Sama’s idea. It’s practiced from Nagasaki all the way to Edo. You’re the last priest left here now, Padre. I’m sure Inoue Sama would be pleased to put an end to the pit. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 102 INTERPRETER (cont'd) He is only a practical man, Padre, he is not a cruel one. Ferreira leans in. He still speaks quietly, but his tone becoming increasingly emphatic.

dialogues.speaker: FERREIRA
dialogues.text: I have been in this temple for a year. I have labored in this country for fifteen years. I know it better than you. Our religion does not take root in this country.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Because the roots have been torn up!

dialogues.speaker: FERREIRA
dialogues.text: No! Ferreira’s tone has changed. He speaks now with resolutio almost with vehemence. There is no trace of the tear Rodr thought he saw only moments before. The light has returne his eyes. FERREIRA (cont'd) Because this country is a swamp. Nothing grows here. Plant a sapling here and the roots rot.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: There was a time when Christianity grew. And flourished.

dialogues.speaker: FERREIRA
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: In your time, Father. Before you became like...

dialogues.speaker: FERREIRA
dialogues.text: Like who? Like them? Rodrigues, please listen. The Japanese only believe in their distortion of our gospel. So they did not believe at all. They never believed.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: How can you say this? From the time of Saint Francis Xavier, through your own time, there were hundreds of thousands of converts here.  103

dialogues.speaker: FERREIRA
dialogues.text: Converts? Francis Xavier came here to teach the Japanese about the son of God. But first he had to ask how to refer to God. “Dainichi” he was told. And shall I show you their Dainichi. He POINTS to the sky...to the setting sun.

dialogues.speaker: FERREIRA
dialogues.text: (softly) Behold...there is the sun of God. God’s only begotten sun. In the scriptures Jesus rose on the third day. In Japan, the sun of God rises daily. The Japanese cannot think of an existence beyond the realm of nature. For them, nothing transcends the human. They can’t conceive of our idea of the Christian God.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: You're wrong! They worship God Our Lord. They praise the name of Deus!

dialogues.speaker: FERREIRA
dialogues.text: That's just another word for a god they never knew.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: I saw men die for Deus! They were on fire with their faith!

dialogues.speaker: FERREIRA
dialogues.text: Faith in the wrong god! Their god, not ours! And where does our church...your church...consign believers in the wrong God? Your martyrs may have been on fire, Father, but it was not with faith.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: No! I saw them die! Those people did not die for nothing!

dialogues.speaker: FERREIRA
dialogues.text: Indeed not. They’re dying for you.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: And how many did you save when you crushed the image of Our Lord? How many beside yourself?  104

dialogues.speaker: FERREIRA
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Certainly not as many as you may help. In the background, there is the SOUND of bells and the pr chanting sutras.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: You're only trying to justify your own weakness. God have mercy on you.

dialogues.speaker: FERREIRA
dialogues.text: Which god? Which one?. We say... "Mountains and rivers " (stops) I'm sorry. You haven't learned the language thoroughly, have you. There's a saying here. "Mountains and rivers can be moved. But man’s nature cannot be moved." It’s very wise, like so much here. We find our original nature in Japan, Rodrigues. Perhaps it's what's meant by finding God.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: You are a disgrace, Father. I can’t even call you that any more.

dialogues.speaker: FERREIRA
dialogues.text: Good. I have a Japanese name now. And wife. And children. I inherited them all from an executed man. He gets up and WALKS INTO THE LENGTHENING SHADOWS of earl evening. The Old Priest follows him. Rodrigues watches hi with a growing sense of helplessness. If Ferreira gave up faith, what hope can there be for him? The Interpreter STARES at him with such fixity that he se be reading his mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Rodrigues and the Interpreter walk back toward the wai palanquin. The Interpreter gives Rodrigues time to weigh experience of seeing and hearing Ferreira.

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: Well? How do you feel? He has shown you the path of mercy. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERPRETER (cont'd) I hope you take it. Just a single step can set you on your way.  105

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Why don’t you just hang me in the pit?

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: The Inquisitor feels it is better to have you accept our teaching...our country...our life...on your own. It’s better if you see reason for yourself.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Well, it can’t be helped then.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. NEW PRISON RODRIGUES’ CELL DAY 117 The door OPENS, revealing Rodrigues huddled on the floor. Morning light shines in from the outside, illuminating th figure of a LARGE MAN, naked to the waist. The sight of h fills Rodrigues with a sharp sense of dread. The LARGE MAN deftly TIES Rodrigues’ hands behind his bac knots cut.

dialogues.speaker: LARGE MAN
dialogues.text: You’re an animal. You stink like animal flesh. He YANKS the priest to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rodrigues is seated with hands tied in the saddle of a sp horse. He is in the midst of a small procession moving th a crowd.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Where are you taking me now?

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: To the Inquisitor’s office. Once the people in the crowd were curious. Contemptuous. they are openly hostile. They PRESS FORWARD. Guards have HOLD THEM BACK.

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: So, Father, you see how they respect you. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERPRETER (cont'd) You came here for them, and they all hate you. You’re useless, completely useless.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: There are some here who may be praying in the silence of their hearts. At that moment a clod of mud STRIKES Rodrigues on the bac  106

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: And there is the answer to their prayers. There may be people in this crowd who were Christians once. But are there any now?

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Christian martyrs died for these people. Father Ferreira never mentioned them. He’s weak, and he’s trying to make me weak.

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: He’s done fine, don’t you think?

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: We'll see.

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: Are you really looking forward to it, Father? I hear doubt in your words of defiance.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Insult me all you want. You’1ll only give me more courage.

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: You'll need it. Tonight. You’1ll apostatize tonight. You’re a good man, Padre, and you cannot stand suffering. Your own. Or others.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. INQUISITOR’S OLD PRISON CELL NIGHT 119 And two words: LAUDATE EUM. Rodrigues’ fingers moves acro Latin words cut directly into the wall of this new cell, place so hellishly filthy it makes his previous cells see fine inns. His hands stay on the crude letters. They are shaking. A rolls down his cheek. He is terrified. Of what he is sure awaits him. And of how he may act when the inevitable fin comes to him. He prays for strength--and out of despair.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: God help me, Jesus help me, I hear no voice but Ferreira. He knows what I fear. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 120 121 107 RODRIGUES (cont'd) In the garden, You said "My soul is sorrowful even unto death," and the drops of sweat on Your brow were like blood. I would bleed for You. I would die for You, if I knew You. Are You here? There are SOUNDS from the nearby cells.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: You were the joy of my life. Now I am afraid of You. What can I do to feel your love for me again? The sounds from nearby cells continue. They unsettle Rodr even more, although they are strange, hard to identify: sometimes they sound like groans, other times like snores still at other times, like animal sounds. He covers his ears...but now, along with the other sounds the NOISE of a SCUFFLE in the hall. And SHOUTING. This is voice he knows, and does not want to hear. Kichijiro. EXT. INQUISITOR’S OLD PRISON YARD NIGHT 120 OUTSIDE THE CELL: GUARDS ARE PUSHING KICHIJIRO AWAY.

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO GUARD
dialogues.text: I’m a Christian! I’ma Liar! You’re just like us! Christian!

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO GUARD
dialogues.text: Hit me! I don’t care! Get_out of here I said!

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO
dialogues.text: (in English now) Padre! Forgive me! I came to make confession! The Guards advance on Kichijiro. INT. INQUISITOR’S OLD PRISON CELL NIGHT 121 INSIDE THE CELL: Rodrigues can plainly hear Kichijiro bei beaten and pulled away as he cries out...

dialogues.speaker: KICHIJIRO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Forgive me! Forgive me, Padre!  108 Slowly...even reluctantly...Rodrigues pulls his hands awa his ears. He silently utters the words of absolution and the sign of the cross. The strange NOISES grow even louder, more emphatic. Rodrigues is near breaking. He starts to BEAT ON THE WALL the flat of his hand.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: Stop it! Stop that noise! Help! The Interpreter comes to the door of the cell.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUES
dialogues.text: No! Down there! There’s a man in agony and the guard’s sound asleep and snoring like a wild dog.

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: You think that noise is the guard? He turns to Ferreira, who stands behind him half in shado

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: Incredible. Sawano...tell him. Say what it is. Ferreira steps into the cell almost like an apparition.

dialogues.speaker: FERREIRA
dialogues.text: It’s not the guard. And it’s not snoring. It’s moaning. It’s Christians. Five of them in fact. All hanging in the pit. Rodrigues is stunned.
